Muting his natural neurotic charisma through a steely deadpan and constant, unmoving half-frown, Eisenberg proves scarily good not only at inhabiting the piercing, controlled mania of Zuckerberg but also turning him into an oddly sympathetic, Machiavellian antihero, just as easy to respect and even like as to despise – it is easy to picture business majors worldwide taking notes. In contrast, Andrew Garfield brings a far more familiar emotional centre to the film as Zuckerberg's eventually jilted friend and business partner Eduardo Saverin. With a casual, likable aura and welcome strains of humour (one of the best scenes of the film is Saverin's agonized confession at not knowing how to change his own Facebook relationship status), Garfield makes Saverin's fade out from the Facebook all the more upsetting, providing intriguing counterpoint to Zuckerberg's snappy success. Finally, in a gleefully self-reflexive piece of casting, Justin Timberlake oozes glamour and sleaze as the manipulative creator of free music downloading site Napster, not chewing scenery so much as salivating upon it and providing a deliciously detestable face to corporate ambition.

While it may or may not have as much to say about the presence of technology in contemporary social relations, the blurring of the spheres of private and public and the tension between individual or collective success as it may or may not mean to, The Social Network provides an impressively assembled slice of fun and profundity, with all creative talents concerned functioning at the top of their games. Even (or perhaps especially) for those few still to be drawn in by the seductive allure of Facebook, Fincher's film still proves an intriguing and even exhilarating watch, and one of the best films of its year.

'Like'.

-8.5/10

title: You are not an a**h**e, but you are trying so hard to be one..
review: I am an active Facebook user & has got many friends & do spend enough time on checking updates, photos & video's from my friends.I was curious to watch this movie after reading few good review's about it. Movie run time is some 2 hours & some odd minutes, I didn't realize, when it finished, as it was so engrossing & engaging. Jesse(who played Mark Zuckerberg) acted so well that I wouldn't wish to see anyone else to play that character. See him the way, he reacts to Attorney's questions, in a witty though sarcastic way. Andrew Garfield(who played Eduardo Saverin) is another Gem, he pulled the role so well, you would hate him many time being so self-centered. Justin Timberlake gives justice to his role of Sean Parker as a founder of the Napster.Armie Hammer was effective too. There are many rumors about FB, not sure how much true was about it in movie, but surely got the picture, what it takes to be a Punk Genius Billionaire.

title: Entertaining Flick, A Little Over-hyped
review:
The critics are falling all over themselves praising this film, predicting a armload of Oscars for the principals come March, and that could very well happen, but The Social Network doesn't seem like any kind of modern-day classic to me.

What strikes one while watching it is the skillful way Sorkin, Fincher, and the actors can hold your interest for 2 hours with a story about a socially-awkward computer wiz's rise to the top and the pesky lawsuits he had to endure, which seem real important during the film, but eventually result in settlements.

Apparently Fincher can make any subject matter interesting, and Sorkin's rapid-fire script had the audience I watched with hanging on every word. You had to pay attention. If you were distracted for 5 seconds, you might miss 4 lines of dialogue. And while all of it was clever, there were no great truths coming from the actor's mouths. There wasn't much of a theme to latch on to here, other than the irony of a friendless geek creating the biggest social phenomenon on the web. As far as I could tell, everyone just wanted to get paid. Except Justin Timberlake's character who wanted to get laid and high as well. He was great, by the way.

Jesse Eisenberg was also great (again) evolving from his usual intelligent, self-conscious, sensitive guy to an intelligent, self-conscious, insensitive guy. Not much of a leap that Eisenberg manages easily. I didn't hate his character at the end as much as everyone else seems to. Best bud Andrew Garfield and rich guy(s) Armie Hammer were good too.

I guess the lack of real conflict or suspense is the cause for the slight flatness I felt at the end. I knew Zuckerberg was going to come out filthy rich and in the absence of any personal epiphany from him, the fate of his former best bud just wasn't enough to get me emotionally involved. (Don't worry, he got paid -- along with everyone else.)

title: Undecided
review:
I have mixed emotions about this movie. I can't say that it was bad. It was well written, well directed, and the acting was much better than I expected. I can't zero in on any huge flaws in that respect. However, I didn't find it entertaining. Interesting, yes, but I was bored. There is no one to root for. All of the characters are assholes and douche bags, so it makes it hard to care while watching the movie.

I take that back. I liked Rashida Jones' character, but her role was too small for that to matter.

A random tidbit...

Justin Timberlake's performance was great. I didn't like his character, but he was definitely a scene stealer. I liked that the previews did not reveal who he was. The reveal was a bit of a wow moment.

title: With Friends Like These...
review:
The genius of "The Social Network" begins with the story that inspired it. The tagline on its poster, "You don't get to 500 million friends without making a few enemies," perfectly conveys the inherent dramatic irony; royal narcissist Mark Zuckerberg is today the champion of the web's most popular socialization tool, Facebook.

It's rich soil for screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, who imbues the material with his signature wit and a searing theatricality. Frankly, I'm not concerned with what small liberties his brilliant script took along the way—Not that even the most obscene inaccuracy could stymie the momentum he builds. The film is guiltier of embellishment than falsification, a crime for which he and director David Fincher should be awarded our highest praise. Fincher knocks this one out of the park with confident cinematography, nuanced performances from his cast, and layered storytelling that lends the film its surprising depth. On its surface, "The Social Network" is funny, brisk, and compelling, but underneath, it's near rotting with angst.

Its moodiness and purposeful visual melodrama are its most unique assets. Fincher approaches the story from the position of Zuckerberg himself, striving for the honest emotional experience of each scene, with all the grandiosity of a nineteen year old's perspective. To the layman, that means he finds a way to make sitting at a computer, or having a conversation in a crowded nightclub seem invigorating and fresh.

"The Social Network" is immediately in contention as his best film, but as much as Fincher brings to it, the lion's share of the Mark Zuckerberg experience is etched in the long, perpetually unsmiling face of Jesse Eisenberg, who portrays him in the film. Eisenberg has a history of taking on lighter roles in comedies like "Zombieland" that has prompted some to unfairly label him "the poor man's Michael Cera," (though the comments seem to stem from Cera bashers themselves—There's no pleasing those guys). Eisenberg's turn here should slap the cynicism from any remaining doubters' mouths. He owns the role; the callous calculation, the condescending sense of humor, and the introverted inner pain are expertly realized, and yet the true testament to Eisenberg is that Zuckerberg at his worst is a character impossible to truly hate.

And Eisenberg is matched by a cast of equal talent; Andrew Garfield plays Facebook's co- founder, Eduardo Saverin, and Armie Hammer plays both of the Winklevoss twins, who together bring suit against Mark for intelligent property theft. The beauty of each character is that despite their muckraking in the deposition room, which acts as a framing device in "The Social Network," none ultimately feels like the antagonist. As with the best cinematic scuffles, we identify with both sides.

But as beautifully as the stars aligned for what is insofar the best film of 2010, "The Social Network" is somehow more than the sum of its parts. Its underlying themes of capitalist corrosion and the price of success are made all the more poignant given the age of its participants. Fincher has jokingly referred to the film as "The Citizen Kane on John Hughes movies," but he honestly isn't far off. Young love, rebelliousness, arrogance, and burgeoning identity play major roles in shaping the behavior of Sorkin's characters.

And yet, for all their bitterness and hostility, "The Social Network" is still an exciting, encouraging film. Somewhere beneath the veneer, alongside the greased cogs in its innermost workings, the power of Mark's idea gestates. Facebook, as silly and as trivial a subject as it may seem, is for many an essential communicative hub in their day-to-day lives. Watching Zuckerberg succeed beyond his wildest dreams, literally bringing strangers together while pushing his friends away, paints an oddly optimistic portrait.

The future for the internet generation seems bright in Fincher's mind. Even as we make the gradual shift to living our lives electronically, even when we're polluted by a consumer culture, and even when we lose sight of our humanity, some kid can still change the world.

title: Its amazing tempo makes this movie so enjoyable
review:
While watching this movie, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. The movie lasts around 2 hours but to me it seemed like half an hour. All this is thanks to specially a great editing, but also the script and narration that gives this movie an amazing rhythm and tempo. To me, this is by far the best part of this nice movie.

Although the script is not bad, and it also helps to provide this movie with such a nice tempo, fastest movie I've seen since Billy Wilder's "One, Two, Three" (1961). However, I don't find the dialogs as smart as other people do, that consider Aaron Sorkin's scripts very intellectual. Conversations are just normal for me, if you want to see intellectual scripts then I'd refer you to Joseph L. Mankiewicz movies like "All about Eve" (1950) or Igmar Bergman movies.

Also I found some elements of the script a bit artificial and flawed. Starting with the initial scene, where Erica and Mark are having a discussion, then the audience "discovers" that they are in a relationship in a very artificial way, by having one of the characters say it: MARK: "We are dating" this should be the last resource used when screenwriting, same goes for the way they break up just in the next line: ERICA: "Not anymore"

Regarding the photography, and the way Fincher directed actors, It was quite mediocre during the film which doesn't really matter because they weren't really important elements for this movie in my opinion.

Overall I gave this movie a solid grade because I enjoyed watching this movie and in my opinion, entertainment is something that should be appreciated when rating a movie.

title: Have a look!
review:
If you have a somewhat interest in knowing how someone became famous or why his work got so much attention, I really recommend you to go and watch this and If you wanna know about how Facebook was developed, then stop doing everything and go watch this first.

I would strongly recommend to people out there who have a keen interest in coding or someone who has interest in computer science because you guys will relate this movie more to your life.

In my case, this was my first biography movie and after watching this and knowing how he used to tackle the problems and what were the difficulties faced by Mark Zuckerberg, I aroused a great curiosity in knowing about other big companies like Apple, Microsoft etc, and I think that same will be the case with you.

title: Justin Timbersucks
review:
This is a very good film. Fantastically written, fantastic performances (from most). It's a really interesting story, even though Hollywood has taken some liberties with the truthfulness of it, It still all feels so real. This is because this isn't just a story about Facebook, this is a common story of numerous start ups, and friendships. Entrepreneurs slip up and make mistakes, become greedy, back stab their friends, get in business with fools, blow money on foolish things Etc. It's a common tale, and this movie encapsulates it very well.
But again no movie is perfect. I think they made some poor choices when choosing actors and actresses, some of the performances were not good. Especially Justin Timberlake and Dakota Johnson, man i don't think she is a very good actress at all.
This movie has an incredible score might I add.

title: A fast, fun and somewhat dark watch
review:
There's this small lapse when I turn off the player, remain seated on my chair or couch and just reflect on what I experienced. I felt there was some twist, some drama that went missing, that it was too straightforward and easy at times. Then, when I logged on Imdb and started with the review, I realized that there couldn't have been more to it - it was concise, crisp, and perfectly cooked - "golden brown" if you will.

Fincher's portrayal of Zuckerberg is amazing. Do you like this guy for he has done? Do you hate this guy for what he has done? He leaves you vacillating for the entire 2 hours. A word of approval for Jesse who was inch perfect in Zuckerberg's shoes. He brought out the idiosyncrasies of the person to perfection.

Most of you already know some of the plot so no spoilers there, but it'll still make for a very captivating watch on one of those rainy evenings at home. Could this have been done better? I doubt it. Is it a masterpiece? No.

title: Gabe Review #3
review: Really incredible performances all around, especially Eisenberg and Garfield absolute kill it. Not sure it's "historically accurate" but has a great story. Also contains an amazing way of telling the story by flicking between the present and past. Definitely worth a watch even if it isn't all true. Also I want to punch Sean Parker really really hard in the throat.

title: Treason, ambition, Internet
review:
It is never an easy task to adapt a true story, let alone such a recent and contemporary biography. However David Fincher has succeeded. He has done it in the best possible way.
'The social network' tells us how the famous Mark Zuckerberg founded the popular social network 'Facebook'. Fincher tells us a story of power, ambition, and above all treason. All through a script that will jump between different times, each filling the holes that are planted. Although clearly a good script is not enough if there is not a good director behind, and luckily this film finds David Fincher at its highest point. We are probably facing one of his best works so far. Although we must not neglect the great performance provided by Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg, possibly the best one he has performed to date.
One of the most fluid and best worked films that David Fincher has given us, that is 'The social network', despite not being totally perfect, the director knows how to transfer a current story to the cinematographic field in a way that is strong enough so as not to depend on the real protagonists and the name 'Facebook', since the film is capable of supporting itself.

title: Is it not one the coolest thing ever, I mean the social media?
review:
What worked: Screenplay and narrative; the story is so fresh, engaging,stylish, clever and interesting. The movie takes us on a ride at the starting days of Zuckerberg's Facebook. It's hard not to like the casts and characters. The background scores and editing added the flavor. The movie is deep and meaningful too, and I loved the ending of the movie. What did not work:
  • I would have wanted more depth in the character of Mark, maybe his background, his struggles, not only his brilliance and also some contemplation.
Final verdict: Recommended; it's an powerful ride.

title: A Masterpiece
review:
I am not completely sure that if the story of this movie was completely true or not. But if it was I can't help but think that what Wardo went through like laying out the foundation of a multi-billion dollar company and one of the most famous social media application then getting a settlement and an NDA. He was totally wronged.

And also in terms of movies: Beautifully directed, amazing storyline (doesn't matter fictional or not) and great acting... Personally I would at least nominate Andrew and Jesse for an Oscar for this acting!

title: The Social Network - 77
review: A amazing character selection and performance by both new and old stars like Andrew Garfield and Justin Timberlake. Which result in an very interesting in-depth biography of how a Harvard student created one of the most profitable business idea of the 21 century, Facebook. But, you already knew the majority of the story of Facebook and while It is nicely directed and entertaining to watch it on film, it wasn't that enthralling. In addition the story didnt get me as emotionally pumped as it could have been, thus it didn't add up do much in the end.

title: Wish I Watched It Sooner!
review:
I can not believe I put off watching this film for a whole decade (granted I was ten at the time of its release haha). Although I had to immediately search up if all of the information portrayed was accurate moments after the credits began rolling (sorry to say but the truth is overdramatized according to various sources), it was an incredibly well done film.

Though 2 hours in length, The Social Network had me wishing it was even longer. There was not a single moment I was not enticed by what was occurring in the story; from the absolute second it starts you are immersed into the incredibly baffling mind of Mark Zuckerberg and all those who contributed to the creation of Facebook.

If you are looking for a somewhat educational film that emphasizes on the drama and crime, then I highly recommend The Social Network.

title: Andrew Garfield is stunning
review: Wow this movie was good. How did Garfield not win an oscar!!! Dave fincher is one of my favorite directors maybe even my favorite. Jesse Eisenberg is also fantastic in this. What a movie

title: Compelling story and acting
review: It's not a very glamorous story but David Fincher does a good job of adapting it to the big screen. The best part was the acting. Although this shows the founding of a modern company, it does not seem like it imposes a stance on the company and it works as a compelling story in its own right.

title: A semi-accurate history, but a transcendent movie
review: When I first saw this film in 2010, I definitely recognized Sorkin's brilliance and Fincher's craftsmanship (always)...but I kept getting distracted by accuracy questions. Why did they change Zuckerberg from socially awkward to the most confident and eloquent nerd ever? Why did they leave out his then-girlfriend and now-wife? How much of this story was true? Revisiting the movie in 2020 was very different (and not just because Zuckerberg feels more and more like Eisenberg these days). I was able to just watch it as a movie. This film tells a company's origin story through depositions and flashbacks. That should not work. But it does. From Resnor's score ramping up the intensity to the brilliant pacing/cuts to the pitch perfect performances of Sorkin's dialogue, this story just cooks. No matter where you come in, you HAVE to keep watching. And for once Sorkin's resists explaining his theme through speeches over and over. You just see the way connection and isolation coexist, for the main character and honestly for yourself. It is all pretty brilliant, and it was worth a second watch, for sure. Is it accurate? Somewhat. Is it a great film? One hundred percent.

title: The Boring Network
review: Here's a movie about a bunch of white people arguing over who made a website. Cool. You've also got a white man playing a Brazilian man, and don't forget about the other white man playing an Indian man. There was also that joke about trans people. You're all rich. Get over it.

title: Blogging never ends
review: Blogging is very inspired to mark Zuckerberg after blogging coading, ultimate cool ideas will come, this ideas changed range from univ, to number of schools, cities, countries, Facebook continents, coading is going on awesome

title: Fincher's masterpiece.
review:
Looking back in the past decade, The Social Network was the one movie I had to settle the score with. I have lost count of how many times I have watched it now and every time I watch it, the movie gets better and better. This is Fincher's best work in terms of critically acclaimed and award winning and I can definitely see why.

The reason why this movie works so well and it doesn't becomes one of those generic and boring biopics is the tone. Fincher creates the whole tone of the film using the cinematography and the score to absolute perfection. The way certain scenes are presented, the way Fincher uses closeups and the score to elevate the scene is amazing. The movie has some of the most dis-likeable actors for me (Jesse Eisenberg and Justin Timberlake) acting in it, but I have to say that they do a really good job at keeping up with the level of everyone else involved in this film. And you can argue that that's Fincher pushing them to the limits of their potential. Now apart of Fincher, one of the other reasons this movie works so well is because of the screenplay. It feels like you can do no wrong with a screenplay written this well. I think that the reason why the viewing experience gets even better each time you watch it, it's because of the screenplay. There is so much in it, given so fast, so slick that it's hard to absorb it all in one or two viewings. This is a very rare screenplay and Fincher knew it for deviating from his usual genre and do this biopic. The script it's so detailed, it's slick, it's sharp, it's smart and witty and I love it.

Overall, it is a fantastic film. It's one of those films you can't wait to pass some time so you can watch it again and that is the best compliment I can give to a film.

title: Good storyline and very interesting
review: Surprisingly this movie was actually really good was very interesting to know how Facebook got created. The start of the film was a little slow and boring but as it went on it got better. Social network had a great cast and Jesse Eisenberg was absolutely brilliant in playing the part. So if anyone is reading this give it a chance it's a good film

title: Will go down as one of the best movies in history,with unbelievable performances from it's stellar cast.
review: Every cast member was unbelievably amazing, starting from Eisenberg's career best portrayal of the college kid who changed the world, just watch the lawsuit scene with the winklevoss twins and you'll know what I am talking about, and Andrew Garfield's Eduardo Saverin was spectacular, the loyal friend who is soon to become the worst enemy, which he wonderfully demonstrated in the confrontation scene between him and mark, delivering a masterclass performance as he showed Eduardo's disappointment and anger , Justin Timberlake did an amazing job representing the eccentric, greedy entrepreneur,Armie Hammer was amazing too , The entire movie just get's into your head and once you start watching , you can't stop,The significance of this movie is it's relevancy,How people had to know about that new entity that would shape their current life and their future. Everything from screenplay to soundtrack was at it's optimum state, David Fincher did an amazing job which i doubt that anyone else could've done. The movie isn't just about the success and rise of Facebook, At it's core it's a tragic representation about how those once inseparable friends turned on each other because of greed or power.

title: The Social Network
review: David Fincher directs "The Social Network". A film detailing the events of Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg creating the social networking site that would become known as Facebook, and how he is sued by the twins who claimed he stole their idea, and by the co-founder who was later squeezed out of the business. This film is a very well made and captivating film. The performances from Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield are stunning standouts. Fincher directs this film in a great way, as its riveting score, excellent editing, and cinematography, give this film which doesn't necessarily deal the darkest of subjects, a somewhat intense and dark aesthetic to it. The script is brillant, as this is a film that relys heavily on dialogue, so the script had to be great. This film deals with true events, leaving it no room for narrative creation, but it still packs a heavy punch. As this film is relevant, important, sophisticated, engaging in every way, and depicts the relations of business and ideas, and the choices that lead to the future. The film really explodes in a good way when the arguments over rights and business opportunities happen between Zuckerberg and Savrin. Jesse Eisenberg turns the character into someone you'd love to hate, yet cant quite seem to, as he is a very sensible and intelligent asshole. The dialogue is slick and powerful, and the way the past and at the time present is interwoven together is masterfully crafted and structured. This film is razor sharp in many ways. The film is not intense in the usual way, but more through dialogue and the emotion of characters. And in the end, Mark Zuckerberg realizes his petty nature. The film is about relationships and freinds and what they mean in the digital age. He feels bad for screwing Eduardo, and using him. Mark spends most of the film attempting to distinguish himself. Eduardo saw through Sean's facade, while Mark didn't. Mark is just trying to make Facebook the best that it can be, until the end, he does the first human thing of the entire film, and reaches to someone, expressing remorse. Or, it could be seen as Mark revealing his shallow nature, and depicting his isolation, even though he has money and power.

title: love this
review:
At last, a movie you can actually discuss afterward. And not just on Facebook or Twitter. No, you'll want to chew it over in person, with friends, for hours.

When was the last time that happened?

The movie would be "The Social Network," the highly anticipated collaboration between director David Fincher ("The Curious Case of Benjamin Button") and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin (TV's "West Wing"), which has its Friday night at the gala opening of the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. (The movie opens wide Oct. 1.)

The complex drama, about the founding of Facebook and the conflicting claims over who deserved credit for its invention, lives up to the hype. "Social Network" is smart, lively, well-acted and - this is key - raises questions and issues that are both timeless and totally of the moment.

Oh, sure, you probably spent time palavering after seeing "Inception" this summer, but that was trying to figure out just what the hell actually happened. How many dream levels were there again? And why were they mucking around in all that snow near the end?

In a way, "Social Network" seems almost a throwback to the great movies of the late 1960s and '70s. It taps into the zeitgeist. It's about what's happening now. Right now. And it has a viewpoint - well, actually, a bunch of them.

In the same way that "Bonnie and Clyde," "Taxi Driver" and "The Godfather" were all provocative films, so is "Social Network." Like those earlier movies (but without the torrent of bullets and actual blood), it raises questions about who's good, what's right and the definition of success in America.

"Social Network" begins in late 2003 with dweeby 19-year-old Harvard-ite Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) getting dumped in a noisy bar by his girlfriend (Rooney Mara). He goes back to his dorm room, begins drinking and writes vicious hurtful things about her on his blog, including revealing her bra size. Classy guy.

Immediately afterward, on a tear, he hacks into the Harvard computer system and creates a site called Facemash. It features the faces of two female students side by side, and viewers are asked to rate which one is hotter. Within hours, the site has received more than 20,000 hits and crashes the Harvard server.

It's Revenge of the Nerds, writ small. Soon it becomes Revenge of the Nerds, writ large.

Zuckerberg, socially inept but always the smartest guy in the room, goes on to conceive the idea for Facebook, the now global social network that has made him into the world's youngest billionaire.

Or does he? Because success has many fathers while failure is an orphan, there are competing claims for Facebook's founding. While no one argues that it was Zuckerberg's brains and programming skills that built the system, he later faced legal challenges from other Harvard-ites who claimed they, too, had been there at the social network's birth.

These competing claims, both in the deposition room and in flashback, make up the heart of the movie. One comes from Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Garfield), a fellow geek and Zuckerberg's self-described best friend, who provides the seed money for Facebook. The second lawsuit is filed by Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, twins who are everything that Zuckerberg and Saverin are not: socially skillful, preppy and successful athletes. (They rowed crew at Harvard and later in the Olympics.)

title: Rule of cool
review:
The movie is actually pretty cool, the Mark Zukerberg that is played by Jesse Eisenberg has a lot of charm, and that they have been portrayed him as an asocial geek, but with a shred of humanity was a great idea, his interactions and conflicts with others helps to create his character and the side characters are also good... although, the Winklevoss twins could have been better since they hardly have any background or interaction with any situation, beyond being the antagonists of the film.

The exposition was good, since the protagonist is surrounded of much juvenile madness just like drink games, parties, red-hot dialogues, helping to do a pleasant road throughout all the movie.

title: Yes, I'm writing this in 2020
review:
I was not very impressed when I first saw this in 2010 and gave it a 7/10, it's a very good movie, not a perfect one. But then I realized I keep coming back to this movie every now and then. It's that kind cinema "magic" chemistry that pulls me back once a year or so.

I guess the fact that I'm a computer engineer and entrepreneur myself contributes to this too, but mainly it's the prefect blend of the pace, the writing, the dialogs, the acting and Trent Reznor's soundtrack that make this all happen.

I give it 9/10 (and not 10/10) because of the ending tho. It comes... unexpected, even looks like something was cut out during the edit phase.

title: A Very Entertaining Life Story
review: The Social Network tells the story of how Facebook was created. It seems like it should be just a lot of boring geniuses arguing over code, but it ends up being a super interesting story. With excellent acting and dialogue the movie grips you immediately, and it never lets you go, this movie is as fast paced as the way Zuckerburg talks. The Social Network is a movie that I recommend to people who enjoy dialogue focused films.

title: Young
review: The world belongs to young people. Young people don't need to follow the rules. They just need to create the rules. Young people can gain a foothold by stretching their personality. It also inadvertently tells everyone that the information age is an era of robbers, and everything must be fast. Not to mention any delays, everything should be resolved in the fastest and decisive way. The movie also shows that no matter how advanced the development of technology is, how people coexist is the most basic problem to be solved by a society.

title: Great movie !!
review: This movie really gave us in inside on how the creation of Facebook happened and how there was challenges through the years of Mark Zuckerberg. This movie also gives us a side of Mark Zuckerberg that not most people know.

title: True friendship
review: I like the moving. It was a good movie. It did show how a simple idea could be turned into something big. title: Absolutely Stunning!
review: This movie on first viewing was a spectacle to my brain. It doesn't use flashy special effects or action but instead uses flashy dialogue and editing to really keep the viewer watching. The snappy, clever dialogue thats written makes every line rememberable and it really stuck to me days after watching it. The acting was amazing, especially from Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg, Andrew Garfield as Eduardo Saverin and even Justin Timberlake as Sean Parker. The acting, pacing, dialogue all comes together so perfectly that the scene resonates so well afterward. Rewatches are even more entertaining because you can pick out new info and touches you never saw during the times before. Its the only movie I rewatched twice after I saw it for the first time. Brilliant!

title: The Network of friends.
review:
David Fincher, one of the best directors of the last decades, opens the decade (2010s) with a film about the creation of Facebook and that is practically a speech about how the social network would conquer our time and plant a digital era.

Of course, Fincher's style is present, which combines perfectly with an incredible script, giving the suspense and relevance to the story. Editing and music are other elements that are incredible in history and are condensed into an impressive scene, which is the scene in the restaurant with Sean Parker.

The film criticizes everything that surrounds the creation of Facebook, and criticizes a digital society that would arise due to it, which seeks to replace reality with something else, just as Mark replaces the loss of Erica creating Facebook, but that in the end that does not It is enough for him and he feels empty and sends the friend request to her.

So Mark is a reflection of this society that would come, because although he created the "network of friends" he lost his only friend in the process.

title: Exceptional Film, Only One Flaw
review: Overall, the movie was very well directed and sophisticated. In fact, the only flaw I found with this movie is that it may have been a bit too sophisticated at times. As someone who is not as technologically savvy as Mark Zuckerberg, I often found it hard to understand what he was talking about. Although I am aware that the reason Jesse Eisenberg's lines (as Mark Zuckerberg) were so advanced in vocabulary was to portray Mark as accurately as possible, it made it hard for viewers such as myself to fully grasp what was going on. Other than that, this film was astounding. It really helped me get to know Mark as more than just the founder of Facebook. When I first learned that we would be watching this film in class, I had very low hopes to be quite honest, as I had never even heard about this movie before. I am glad that I was wrong, and I actually ended up liking this movie very much. It was about more than just the creation of Facebook. It was about friendship and betrayal, as well as supply and demand. In this case, Facebook, allowing its users to connect and interact with one another, is the supply whereas its users' desire to connect with others is the demand. As demand went up, so did the supply, which is what would lead to Mark becoming the youngest billionaire (at that time). Overall, it was an exceptional film and well worth the watch.

title: A great movie about becoming a friend
review: The movie does a great job at making people strongly dislike Mark, showing different situations where he is in a grey to dark grey area of right and wrong. We see his arc fluctuate between being in the wrong to being wronged. Its a great movie that teaches the masses about supply and demand- a wonderful example for economics classes to use as a point of teaching!

title: Incredible
review: The Social Network is one of the best Dramatic movie. Great Direction, Strong Performance, strong screenplay. Films said to us loyalty to your friends.

title: Informative and capturing film
review: Overall, in purely film terms, this film was great. Great storytelling and great acting all round. And as a minor point it's a text book example of a great last shot in a film. Nothing deep but just gets you thinking about something other than money at the moment the film closes. My only fault with the film is that I wouldn't have made it at all. So it turns out that Mark Zucherberg became the youngest billionaire ever by being extremely selfish. That's probably not a surprise but the one good thing about Mark Zucherberg, the one thing that redeems him from creating social media, is that he could be an inspiration for young people to strive for success through education rather than through bullying. Maybe Mark should be exposed as a bad person, however in this case I think the better thing for humanity would actually be to keep that behind closed doors and let him at least be an inspiration for the next generation to work harder at school.

title: Great Story!
review:
Review:
'The Social Network' is a biographical-drama film directed by David Fincher. It is based on Ben Mezrich's 2009 book 'The Accidental Billionaires'.
Who would have thought a movie based off the creation of Facebook would be entertaining, let alone of the best movies of 2010.
On a fall night in 2003, Harvard undergrad and computer programming genius Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) sits down at his computer and heatedly begins working on a new idea. In a fury of blogging and programming, what begins in his dorm room as a small site among friends soon becomes a global social network and a revolution in communication. A mere six years and 500 million friends later, Mark Zuckerberg is the youngest billionaire in history, but for this entrepreneur, success leads to both personal and legal complications.
All the performances in the movie are great. Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg, who has a fast-paced, nerdy, kind of jerk-ish attitude, and Andrew Garfield is his best friend, found me rooting for him through the whole film, even more than Mark. Justin Timberlake does a decent job but is lost among the other performances.
The direction comes from David Fincher who has had variable success, all the way from 'Alien 3' to 'Se7en', but here he is right on form with a flashy, but tightly structured, presentation that never fails to command your attention and interest. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat, which is crazy given the context of the film. Only Fincher could make that happen.
Overall, the movie keeps your attention throughout with great performances and an intriguing story. It shows different sides of one story and how much it took to get Facebook off the ground.
4.5/5

title: Brilliant, Bold, and Heartbreaking
review:
I won't mince words: "The Social Network" is a brilliant film. Brilliant direction, brilliant writing, brilliant acting, and a brilliant score all come together to tell a tale of greed, sex, money, and the irony of a man with a million followers but zero friends. Certain aspects of the film already feel dated, and the ending could use some work, but overall "The Social Network" is a knock-out.

The film isn't all that historically accurate - there was no Erica Albright who inspired Facebook and Zuckerberg wasn't the totally ruthless, emotionless robot Aaron Sorkin makes him out to be. But the movie's story, a classic tragedy of power and broken friendships, is a powerful look into a contemporary world increasingly dominated by social media.

Jesse Eisenberg is stellar as Mark Zuckerberg, who's the perfect protagonist for "The Social Network." While the script exaggerates his many flaws, the movie paints a searing portrait of our modern cultural landscape by choosing to show him as a cold narcissist who is able to create one of the biggest social media phenomenons of all time despite being socially inept. Fincher and Sorkin use Zuckerberg to examine not just Facebook but an entire era where the internet suddenly has the power to change the world in a matter of minutes and the number of followers you have on social media means more than the value of your genuine friendships.

The greatest scene in the movie brings these themes to the surface so beautifully when Eduardo, fed up with Zuckerberg's betrayals, smashes Mark's computer and tells him, "I'm not coming back for 30%, I'm coming back for everything." As Eduardo is escorted out of the building Facebook employees celebrate the milestone of a million users signing up for the website. Mark may have a million followers, but his one true friendship is long gone. Aside from being highly memorable this scene does much to showcase Andrew Garfield's skill an an actor - his performance is by far the best in the film.

As to be expected from David Fincher the technical aspects of "The Social Network" are almost flawless: the movie has such a distinct look and feel that evokes the early 2000s without really becoming a period piece. The editing and pacing are on-point and the score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross is a driving, brutal soundtrack that animates the film's endless scenes of code writing, computer hacking, and litigation that might otherwise have been dull. Although there's a few points in the film where the score becomes repetitive, and the usage of dubstep is unneeded, the music is still impressive.

"The Social Network" was certainly one of the best films of 2010, but that doesn't make it a perfect movie. The film overuses obscure technical jargon, especially in the first act, and the ending just doesn't cut it. After two hours of gripping drama the movie screeches to an abrupt halt with a finale that contradicts the whole premise of the main narrative: a young lawyer tells Mark that although he's not a bad person, he "tries so hard to be." In contrast, nearly everything that Mark said or did throughout the movie showed that he's a jerk even to his best friend but doesn't care - and maybe doesn't even realize it. He isn't trying to be a bad person, he just is and that's what ironically resulted in Facebook. The ending doesn't ruin the movie by any means but it does undermine its central theme.

Further, the movie already feels dated. Mark's petty rivalries and backstabbing now appear quaint in a time when the real Zuckerberg has been accused of selling Americans' personal information to the Russians, who may or may not have swung the 2016 election to a man who himself is very much a product of our chaotic social media landscape. The movie's story is still compelling and entertaining, but I almost wish that Fincher and Sorkin had waited another ten years to make "The Social Network" so that these newer and more interesting questions could've been addressed. "The Social Network" is imperfect but nonetheless it's a towering artistic achievement that well-deserved its critical praise and box office success. 9/10.

title: Lots of drama infusion to make the movie more interesting...
review: A lot of events that are portrayed in the movie did not happen in real life, but that's not to say that a lot of events in the movie did happen. however. Mark Zuckerberg did not have a girlfriend that he broke up with that made him begin The Facebook, he had the girlfriend then that he is with now. I also found the movie VERY degrading towards women, as they were portrayed as dumb, emotional drama queens that wore fancy makeup and suggestive clothing who were either stripping, sleeping with the men, or completely unaware of the men's entrepreneurial ideas. The ONLY reason I had to give the movie 2 stars instead of 1 is because I loved Trent Reznor's soundtrack to this movie. Bravo to him.

title: One of the most interesting character dramas made
review:
The Social Network was never a film on my radar but upon hearing that David Fincher directed it and Aaron Sorkin wrote it, I had to go check this film out. I have no regrets.

The Social Network is definitely one of the most engaging dramas I've had the pleasure of watching. Everything was pretty much bang on. Fincher's direction was immaculate. Every scene was clear and had a great style to it. What really stood out to me was Sorkin's script. I knew Sorkin was one of the best scriptwriters working today but here I was just in awe at his work. Each and every dialogue felt captivating and added a lot of personality to everyone's character especially Mark Zuckerberg. The cinematography was top-notch and the music throughout felt very fitting to whatever was going on in the scene.

Jesse Eisenberg owned the role of Zuckerberg. He delivered his lines so well and proved to me that he is capable of handling a serious role. Andrew Garfield and Justin Timberlake were also perfect in their roles and gave their best performances.

Even if the film is factually inaccurate at times, the drama and conflict that takes place between the characters creates such an investing experience that you tend not to think about what aspects of the film are true or false.

I would highly recommend The Social Network. On a technical level this movie is outstanding. The direction by Fincher and screenplay from Sorkin provides us an engrossing insight into the troubles faced by Zuckerberg after the creation of Facebook. This film has to be watched if you've never seen it.

title: A regular movie
review: The history of zuckerberg, not a great movie but is a good movie.

title: For all intents and purposes of the film, Eisenberg is on the mark.
review: David Fincher's internet epic is an incisively written and impressively controlled biopic where captivating legal drama meets new-media ambition. Jesse Eisenberg exudes a scary confidence and insensitivity in this relentless character study.

title: Andrew Garfield steals the show!
review: Jesse Eisenberg is obviously brilliant in this movie as he is in almost everything he does. But I massive shoutout to Andrew Garfield who manages to steal the show from great performances from Jesse Eisenberg and Armie Hammer. The scene were Eduardo Saverin is screaming at Sean and Mark for cutting him out of Facebook is incredible, he owns the role

title: Best Biopic of 2010.
review:
Watched this for the nth time! This film is one of the masterpieces of modern cinema, David Fincher managed to make a film about an autobiography, something that give a fictional air and I really appreciate it. Also, the lines. Aaron Sorkin did a great job as a screenwriter!

The cast is a perfect thing, I really could believe that Jesse Eisenberg was the real Mark Zuckerberg (I love this man), two Armie Hammer. Andrew Garfield as Eduardo Saverin shines the most. I could not love this movie more!

title: Excellent!
review: This is one of the few movies that I can keep coming back to. When it starts out, we see Mark with his girlfriend. She basically breaks up with him. We see him and his friends at Harvard and soon after he starts developing Facebook. The movie cuts between a meeting with his lawyer and those suing him to the events leading up to Facebook. I found it fascinating. They made it so dramatic and draw you into the story. Definitely recommended! 10/10.

title: There is nothing flaw on this Facebook pages
review: Everything is so smooth and the storytelling is absolutely flawless

title: He's More Fred C. Dobbs or Charlie Kane than Daniel LaRusso!
review:
Absolutely brilliant, and very hard to define. Is it a drama? A satire? A coming of age story?

I went to Columbia University in the Reagan Eighties, and I hated every minute of it. This movie captures the environment perfectly -- spoiled rich kids, binge-drinking, callous administrators, self-impressed instructors, hatefulness and evil triumphing over ideals and hope. Man, I hated Columbia. And I loved this movie for explaining why.

Yet at the same time I hated this movie, because it's so craven and so desperate to uphold the status quo. In terms of tone it's really not so much a modern KARATE KID as it is a mash-up of CITIZEN KANE and TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE.

Except that John Huston treats his bums with a lot more compassion than this movie treats its heroes.

title: One of the best movie I have ever seen
review: This is the 2010 Oscar season's first drama to live up to the hype and expectations associated with it.

title: Great movie that shows Zuckerberg is an a-hole
review: Well done movie that shows the story how The Facebook came to be, and how Zuckerberg scammed some others on the way. This movie is from 2010, and since then Zuckerberg has confirmed by his actions that he indeed is just the a-hole this movie depicts him to be. Privacy and free speech have become concepts alien to FB. Google's motto once said "don't be evil", before it was removed, but once money seriously kicks in, it only gets worse, as lust for money is the root of all evil. Looking out for the sequel!

title: great lessons from this movie
review:
I have watch the social networks film , and i enjoy it with my friends
I learn some lessons from this movie
one , is about how can you move bigger with your project when you partner with other people who have resources that your project need.
And vice versa when you prefer to do everything on your own and wait until you have the resources to expand your project, while other may still your Idea and build a project bigger than yours And then they precede you.

title: Insightfully Meaningful
review:
1 March 2014. After three years of avoiding watching this film because I knew I wouldn't like it, especially the title character, perhaps I had been channeling Steve Jobs or something, but now that the deed is done, I must admit I was wrong. There is subtle elegance in how all the characters came across. What makes this movie so meaningful and powerful is its deliver of non-stereotypical, flat, overly dramatic characters and instead the audience is offered up a more complex and deliciously appealing set of characters that seem real and sympathetic in almost every person presented. I enjoyed how the movie ended and how each character seemed to be a victim of the system of economics of business development, each with their own honorable take on how it should be.

This movie isn't so much about right and wrong, but how one's own personal identity interacts with the innate conflicts and tensions of anything new. There is both sufficient anger and sympathy to go all around. While I didn't like the constant flashback technique used in this movie as the background method of presenting the main story, I can't really come up of another way it could have been done, which says a lot in itself.

title: Hard To Believe... My Favourite Movie
review: The Social Network is an incredible film. I know it's edgy to say that it's my favourite of all time, but it really is. I could watch it over and over, it just never gets old. The score is phenomenal, the directing is exquisite, the screenplay is incredibly written with snappy dialogue and great storytelling, performances are just top-notch, cinematography is beautiful, everything is brilliant! The idea of the creation of Facebook might not appeal to some, but this is surprisingly a captivating and moving story. Cheers to Aaron Sorkin.

title: This is the 2010 Oscar season's first drama to live up to the hype and expectations associated with it.
review: David Fincher's internet epic is an incisively written and impressively controlled biopic where captivating legal drama meets new-media ambition. Jesse Eisenberg exudes a scary confidence and insensitivity in this relentless character study.

title: Recommended if you like dramas with comedy elements and are interested in Zuckerbergs story
review:
Finally came around to watching the most popular movie about mr. Zuckerberg and the founding of his little website..

The film opens with Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) at Harvard University in 2003. Mark was just dumped by his girlfriend Erica (Rooney Mara) for being a jerk. His reaction to this is to post insulting things about her on his blog while simultaneously hacking the University database to illegally download pictures of all the female members and drinking lots of beers. With the help of his best friend Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Garfield) he uses the downloaded pictures to create the website "Facemash" (which ranks two girls and the user picks the hottest), which is so popular that in a short time it crashes the whole University computer network. The University is not pleased but Mark's website did draw the attention of three Harvard upper-class members, Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss and their business partner Divya Narendra, who have an idea for a social network featuring exclusive Harvard members and aimed at dating. They ask if Mark likes to join their project as a programmer. Mark agrees to work on their project but then starts to create his own online social network called 'thefacebook', funded with the help of Eduardo and leaves the Narendra and the Winklevoss brothers in the dark of what he is really doing. When he launches thefacebook website it immediately becomes a success, which infuriates the Winklevoss brothers who blame him for stealing their idea. Things get more and more tense when thefacebook grows and Mark draws the attention of playboy and Napster founder Sean Parker (Justin Timberlake), who would like to work with him and make it a billion dollar project..

Overall this is a good movie; I really liked the chemistry between the main characters (Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield, who stole the movie for me) and it's story kept me watching even though you already know what happens (I guess everybody knows what Facebook is during this day and age). The supporting cast did a fine job as well and I was surprised by the performance of Justin Timberlake (or was he just acting as himself..? ). The message of the movie is clear (the young techs are coming!) and it leaves it to the viewer to make up your mind about Zuckerberg true intentions.

What bugged me the most in this movie is that they portrayed Zuckerberg as a lonely nerd and that he was still lovesick about some girl he dated years ago. The real Zuckerberg was in a relationship during the time this movie takes place and he married his girlfriend in 2012, which is a huge difference with the Zuckerberg we see in the movie. It's also interesting that they tell the story in a flashback style with the courtroom being the present time but it's sometime a little bit difficult to follow what event happened first. But despite this it's a fine movie with good acting, some comedy moments and an interesting story about how one of the biggest websites ever was founded.

Check out this film if you like dramas with some comedy elements and are interested in Zuckerbergs story and the rise of Facebook. But don't expect it to be 100% accurate. (as is usual in biography's)

title: Beautifully scored, beautifully shot, amazing acting, awesome score
review: This movie is just the epitome of all things great. Each scene flows seamlessly into the next, the line delivery is superb, and the soundtrack matches each scene perfectly. And the shots in this movie! The camerawork is great! A must see!

title: "I like standing next to you, Sean. It makes me look so tough."
review: The Social Network, to this day, still encompasses, in my mind, possibly the most well-inscribed screenplay of all-time. Fincher and Sorkin have managed to make, seemingly, the most mundane anecdote into the most dramatic, prodigious, (loosely) based-on-a-true-story, cutthroat tale of the 21st Century. (Verdict: A+)

title: Not what I expected
review: This movie was not what I was expected, granted though I had never read the synopsis. I expected a group of friends creating Facebook and having fun. That was about 5 minutes of the movie. It was a lot darker and sadder than I expected. Most of the characters made me mad, I seriously only loved Dakota Johnson's character. I hate Justin Timberlake even more now. Last thing to add, I love love love Andrew Garfield but WHY is he playing a Brazilian named Eduardo.

title: THE SOCIAL NETWORK
review: Earlier there was an enemy with an idea but they bore a sister and a brother but now we have no connection with the republicans.

title: entertaining, well-constructed, educational
review: The Social Network is a drama movie portraying Facebook's creation. The movie follow Mark Zuckerberg as he figures out what the Facebook platform is going to be while dodging lawsuits. The action is engaging with the writers having done a phenomenal job of staying as accurate to the story while at the same time creating a captivating film. Jesse Eisenberg did an outstanding job at portraying Mark as an anti-social genius. Furthermore, Andrew Garfield did an excellent job of making the audience root Eduardo Saverin. It's an entertaining and solid flick everyone should see.

title: Very well characterized and directed movie, well-rounded and enjoyable
review: The Social Network is a classic clean, well cut, directed, and written movie that is easy to watch and makes you think. Eisenberg is wonderful in the role of Zuckerberg, and paints a realistic and ambiguous picture of a complex man with a big modern influence. I always find true story movies like this to be wild, and extremely valuable to watch. Nothing in the story blows you away, and the ending is lifelike (obviously, as it's based on what really happened) in that it wasn't overly dramatic and not all characters had clean, deserved endings. A very satisfying, well-rounded film.

title: REMARKABLE!
review: This is a film which simply shouldn't work, but it does - magnificently. A story centred on a teenager who becomes the world's youngest billionaire, a web site that reaches a million users in two years, and a cast of real life characters with names like Zuckerberg and Winklevoss just shouldn't be possible. A convoluted tale of raw conflict on the origins of a new type of web site should not lend itself to an expensive movie as opposed to a television documentary. It succeeds because it is not about the technology but about creativity and conflict and about friendship and betrayal. It succeeds because of a magical combination of accomplished direction, scintillating dialogue and superb acting.

title: Fantastically Written
review:
The screenplay from Aaron Sorkin really makes this film. It makes what could have been a boring concept thrilling and absorbing. The dialogue is so visceral and quick-fire that I never lost interest despite not knowing all the jargon being used. David Fincher's direction is focused which really helps keep the narrative flowing. I never found myself bored because of the excellent combination of writing and direction.

Jesse Eisenburg's performance as Mark Zuckerberg is thrilling as he plays what is almost an insufferable genius to perfection, whilst his performance is grounded by the excellent Andrew Garfield as Eduardo Saverin, the co-founder of Facebook. No character is truly moral, all working with their own agendas and interests which creates realistic conflict. When Saverin confronts Zuckerberg about his shares in the company being diluted it ends up being one of the best scenes in the film because of this.

There also must be a mention to Justin Timberlake's portrayal of Sean Parker, who is the closest thing to an antagonist in the film, with how he clashes with Saverin and in effect forces him out of Facebook.

The only issues I had with the film was when it cut back to the lawsuit going on in the present day, as I felt it disrupted the pace of the narrative somewhat, and that the ending seemed a little abrupt.

I know the subject matter has probably been somewhat glamourised to make the narrative more entertaining, but it certainly succeeds there.

title: A Stunning History of Facebook
review: While this may not be 100% acccurate to what Mark Zcukerberg says happened, its still a thrill. By the end you realize you're cheering for the bad guy and yet you feel like you can really realte to the stuggles of owning your own ideas. Easily in the top 20 of the 21st century.

title: 9 out of 10 people will "Like" this movie
review:
The Social Network Review In American cinema, the "get rich or die trying" mantra is exemplified in several figures from the rugged frontiersman out in the old west (The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly and the Revenant), the business tycoon (Citizen Kane and Wolf of Wall Street), and the various American gangsters fulfilling their ethnic stereotypes (Godfather, Scarface, and the Departed). These figures in these movies have many positive qualities like bravery, craftiness, and determination, however, they also have many vices, greed, and thirst for power is the most notable.

In David Fincher's, the Social Network our protagonist is no different. Mark Zuckerburg, played by Jesse Eisenberg, personifies a new generation of anti-hero the jaded and insecure computer nerd. Mark feels he needs to distinguish himself from others, while at the hyper-competitive Harvard. Mark's motivation to be better, however, turns into an obsession. This obsession to be the best jeopardizes his relationship with everyone who is close to him like his girlfriend and best friend.

The Social Network succeeds like a good gangster flick by showing how Mark's time at Harvard and his determination to succeed turned him into a monster or as the film would call an "asshole." An interesting question driving the film is Mark an individual "asshole" or a byproduct of a narcissistic society? By answering the question about Mark, it should also make you take a moment to pause and question yourself and wonder if you have ever been an asshole.

What makes this protagonist so well done is that Mark's online experiences are relatable for many young people watching the film. In a new era where everything is online from how 'beautiful' people think you are to messages about your ex that you wish you could take back. The Social Network covers a lot of ground about these brand new social dynamics that are still in 2017 are little discussed, and it seems like little resistance to social media is given.

In 2010 Facebook was the premier social network, but now the number of apps is only growing from twitter, snapchat, Instagram, tinder, and myspace to a name a few (okay I am making a joke about the last one no one still uses myspace). But these new social networking sites have influenced the way humans interact and how we view each other in our societal hierarchy. The networks have changed society with little resistance, and little discussion and the Social Network does an excellent job in trying to tackle this issue.

You will have to watch the movie to see if Mark is ever free from being "wired in" but it will defiantly make you reconsider both the utility of social networking sites like Facebook and the need to be the best. In sum, excellent acting and a thoughtful and original script make it worth at least one watch. The only con is that the secondary characters have little arc as the protagonist Mark takes center stage. Therefore the film could have been stronger if the other characters like Eduardo and Sean weren't so flat and linear.

title: "I don't want friends."
review: I'm guessing, without really knowing, that Mark Zuckerberg would have heavily lobbied against this film ever coming out. It's not exactly flattering in it's portrayal of the man as a socially inept, should I say it, total a..hole, and it's a credit to Jesse Eisenberg that he was able to pull off the characterization so successfully. One thing I really couldn't figure out about Zuckerberg from watching the movie was what really motivated him. It probably had to do with creating something that exceeded anyone's expectations, because I didn't get a sense that he was in it for the money. Most folks would be, which is why the betrayal aspect of diluting Eduardo Saverin's (Andrew Garfield) ownership stake came across as so, so underhanded. What's ironic in the final analysis is that Zuckerberg wound up with five hundred million 'friends' on Facebook when in real life, he had all he could do to maintain one, and he blew that up pretty successfully. That was in 2010 when the movie came out. Facebook is about to achieve two billion! users at it's current pace, sometime in 2017 as I write this. That's over twenty five percent of the world's population! As a contrarian, I've never joined and have no interest. From what I've read, the site is too intrusive regarding your personal stats, and there are enough eyes watching everything you do as it is, from credit card monitoring to using your cell phone. Impossible to stay off the grid totally, until someone comes up with a reverse Facebook. Maybe then I'll sign up.

title: Should have been a contender
review:
The King's Speech rode the crest of a sentimental wave at the Oscars, and I wonder if the presenter read the wrong winner. Well, at the very least The Social Network should have won Best Picture but I guess it was too gritty and politically incorrect compared to the politically correct and soft King's Speech if you know what I mean.

The performances were incredibly powerful and insightful, and very operatic in a Sorkin kind of way which we expect from the master of the written word.

Perhaps there should be motion pictures based on the rise and fall of MySpace, Flickr (!), del.icio.us, Google+, Digg, Google Wave.

title: Relationship or Money?
review:
Mark Zuckerburg, a student of Harvard University, who becomes famous for an opener of Facebook later on, is claimed by affluent two brothers that Mark steals their ideas and co-founder and Mark's best friend, Eduardo, sues Mark

Before watching the film, I expect that the story will be successful how he has achieved the remarkable feat. However, in the film, his struggling points such as relationship with people and money are described. For instance, he is dumped by his girlfriend, Erica, in order to retaliate against her, he opens a bad site for the use of advantage of his programming ability. One interesting point is that the universally prestigious social network service, Facebook, which is to communicate with others all over the world, is created by a man who is not good at making a good relationship. Even if Mark Zuckerburg is one of the youngest millionaires in the world, he holds no true happiness. This shows that family bond and friendship are crucially significant rather than money.

Yet, according to my search, not everything in the story is based on the true story. Seemingly before producing the film, though the director asks him to have an interview, the director is turned down. Actually, the story is unreliable to seize as Mark Zuckerburg's autobiography, but I believe that the film wants to convey a message to us that relationship makes our life.

title: wrong movie for the title. it was boring and clichéd
review: if mr zuck didn't like this movie, he should have financed his own and overseen the production, starting with the script. that probably wouldn't have been any more accurate than this movie was. i bet the mediation to make sure ALL the facts of all those involved made it into the movie would take infinitely longer than the real life lawsuits shows in the movie. i tried watching it. for a movie about facebook, you know, the social network mentioned in the title, it was all about legal disputes. so what? could have covered all that in about five lines in an epilogue. so what about the book it was based on. boring book that didn't seem to cover the feel good parts of the happy accidents of the world choosing facebook over the already established yahoo360, friendster and myspace who paved the way for facebook that probably otherwise wouldn't exist. mark zuck and co didn't invent social networking as this movie seemingly gives them all the credit for. they got lucky. why was facebook infinitely more successful than its predecessors is what should have been covered as well. it should have also included why no other soc/net never tried after. mind you, twitter, instigram and such are doing well but not to the same extent. why did the world choose f/b over the rest?﻿

title: One of the best films of 2010 for sure.
review: I skipped out on the social network when it first released back in 2010. I was fourteen at the time and watching the promos and trailers for it really only made me think "A movie about Facebook? I'll pass, thanks." but having watched the movie for a second time now after noticing a lot of praise for it, and coming to be a little more accepting to genres and actors I hadn't been very into before and seeing Andrew Garfield's performance in Hacksaw Ridge, I can honestly say this movie is probably one of my favorite of the decade so far. In all honesty it's not a movie about "Will Facebook become successful despite the lawsuit?" since we all know that it does. It's a movie about the deterioration of friendships and how the idea of success can come to change someone. It's beautifully acted and Aaron Sorkin's dialogue is some of the best I've ever seen. It's never boring even at it's slowest and it's definitely worth a watch.

title: A hands-down masterpiece.
review:
I don't know how much I should trust the content of this adaptation. It's pretty safe to assume that Mark Zuckerberg didn't endorse the creation of this movie, but it may have painted him in an unfairly negative light. Regardless of its accuracy, it does illustrate the unfortunate truth that people who are tenacious and don't care about other people are the ones who tend to come out on top. Mark is not found guilty of the charges against him, but he still undeniably violates some serious ethical expectations to achieve his goals. Now, Aaron Sorkin and David Fincher seem to be opposed to Zuckerberg's actions, but at the same time they show him as rather a tragic and unfortunate figure.

The curious thing about the Mark Zuckerberg we see here is that he really seems to want to have friends and a social life, but everything he does hurts his ability to be social. He actually says flat out that he doesn't want friends, but I don't believe that, at least not totally. Maybe I'm mistaking this for him wanting to be accepted, but in the end he fails at being accepted as well. This is highlighted by the way that Mark creating Facebook is shown alongside scenes of people having parties and social lives. And by the end of the movie, he's alienated both of his closest business partners by his possible betrayal of Eduardo and Sean. I guess it's lonely at the top.

Eduardo was the character that I really sympathized with. I disagreed with his stance on wanting to make money with Facebook through ads and stuff, but by the end of the movie I really wanted him to get his own back from Mark. Conversely, I was immediately distrustful of Sean Parker, though I agreed with some of his ideas. Sean has some really cool ideas and forward thinking motivations, but I would much rather work with Eduardo because I would at least know that Eduardo would be a trustworthy and fair business partner. Then there's the Winklevoss twins, who have an understandable gripe in their lawsuit against Mark, but again Mark works around the rules and ignores ethics to come out on top. In a lot of ways, Mark's point that the Winklevosses simply didn't capitalize on their idea is completely true, but that doesn't forgive the fact that he took their idea and ran with it. Finally for characters we have Erica Albright, who doesn't make many appearances but is nonetheless important as the one part of Mark's life where he cannot win.

I thought the execution of this movie was fabulous. First off, Aaron Sorkin's wrote what I think is cinema's best screenplay ever with dialogue that flows naturally and is snappy and relevant and true to each character. Besides that, he intercuts scenes very nicely and seems to have provided each scene with a specific tone. Then the script was put in the very capable hands of David Fincher, who works with DP Jeff Cronenweth to create a tense visual tone that fits the movie's identity and turns it into a work of art. This coupled with the quivering score and pretty good performances from the lead roles made for a riveting two hour masterpiece.

I would recommend this to practically everyone as a pretty good insight into aspects of human behavior. Now, the one caveat I have for that is that it's geared for an adult audience. It may be rated PG-13, but it wants to be R and is not geared for kids. It may not sound like the most riveting story on the surface, but it should keep your undivided attention attention pretty well. It's somewhat complex but I did not find it hard to follow. Finally, for anyone who wants to go into film production, you definitely should see and learn from the best. Overall Rating: 8.7/10.

title: brilliantly entertaining and unique
review:
David Fincher has proved that any premise can be made great with the help of a hardworking and ingenious film crew and cast. The miracle Fincher has achieved in this film is the morphing of a concept that could have more easily been turned into a made for T.V. snoozefest painfully catering to a younger audience into a witty and challenging drama.

From my point of view, those who believe that this film is on the side of any of its characters is surely mistaken. Many critical reviews do not seem to be criticizing the film but the film's subjects, when that is honestly not the way to go. The film itself is mostly neutral when portraying its cast of characters, portraying them as the fascinating and flawed beings they truly are. Almost everyone in this movie is, for lack of a better word, kind of a d*ck. Zuckerberg is among film history's most complex characters, an excruciatingly intelligent man with an endless capability of technological genius, but he is also a man who hurts and betrays others, including those closest to him. He is borderline narcissistic in his ways and, yet again I fail to come up with a better word, often comes across as no more than the standard annoying Harvard smartass. Its a film about the forces of evil, friendship, love, destiny, inspiration, greed, business, conflict, and so on and son.

Rapid fire laugh out loud dialogue is constantly exchanged through one of the most well written and ingenious film scripts of all time. Fincher adapts the boundlessly brilliant script in the best way possible by incorporating his fine visual flare and knack for perfectly paced editing. Seriously, I find this to be among the finest edited films of all time. The editing is able to communicate the feelings of chaos and disorientation throughout without giving the viewer a headache, and entertainment is never sacrificed, for Fincher proves that eh can make any situation as engaging as it possibly can be.

Each and every crucial element of cinema is utilized in the best way possible in "The Social Network". Each performance is pitch perfect (Jesse Eisenberg, Andrew Garfield, and Justin Timberlake all provide some of the finest film performances of the past decade), the editing (as I have already stated) is unbearably incredible, the pacing is highly well done, the subject matter is handled in a way that is mature but not at all devoid of humor, the visuals are beautiful, the soundtrack is amazing, the script is among the greatest ever written, and the film functions as one of the most fascinating and complicated character studies I have ever witnessed. The film offers no easy answers and begs for audiences to think about and question the characters' morals, flaws, and capabilities, as well as their own.

title: Talented Ensemble All Contribute to Create a "Real Life" Story of the New Age
review:
Intriguing Interloping and a Look at something that the Majority of People Rarely get to See. The Creative Process and Seedlings of an Idea that would become a World Wide (Web) Sensation.

Facebook, previously known as "The" Facebook, a Website that Tapped into a Base Desire of Social Interaction, especially of the Young, to find Like Minded Peers, Friends, and "Mates".

It's one of those Things that is a "Why didn't I think of that?" development in the Early Days of the Internet when "Dot Coms" were Crashing and the "Web" was finding its way. Finding its way into the Hearts and Minds of a Generation, and later the Whole World.

It was a Technology that became a Way of Life and two Decades later is still Forming the Consciousness of the People on the Planet. A part of that WWW is Mark Zuckerberg's Website that Dominates Social Media, along with "Twitter" and "You Tube".

This is the Embryosis of that Website, it's Growing Pains that Ends with the Celebration of One Million Subscribers (it now has 500 times more). But getting there is a Human Interest Story of Friends, Acquaintances, Rivals, and Business Partners. There is very Little Conflict in the Creative Process, these Guys for the most part knew Their Craft and knew what They wanted to do.

The Conflict comes in the Form of Intellectual Property, allegedly Stolen and Sued by the Winklevoss Twins, and that Leads Us to Follow the Money. There's Co-Creator Eduardo Savarin, the Financial Adviser and Friend and College Roommate of Zuckerberg who also Sues. He is being "Left Behind" and Replaced with Sean Parker (Creator of Napster).

It's an Artistically Crafted Movie by Director David Fincher, Writer Aaron Sorkin, and an Actor Ensemble that Includes Jesse Eisenberg, Andrew Garfield, Justin Timberlake, and Armie Hammer. The Pounding Soundtrack courtesy of Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross.

The Film may be a bit Overrated but it is Compelling Cinema. One of those that the Entire Production Contributes to its Overall Success, both Artistically and Commercially. Although it's Easy to Dismiss this as a Story of "Spoiled Brats" and "Accidental Billionaires" who Strain for the Everyman to Relate, it certainly cannot be denied that it is a Story of the New Age.

title: The Social Network has well-deserved buzz.
review: The Social Network is a rich, modest and hard-hitting character drama that explores the politics of one of the most beloved and most used social networking internet websites: Facebook. David Fincher (director) captures and explores the egos and personalities behind Facebook. For me, the acting the stole the show was Andrew Garfield, who deserved an Oscar nomination for his performance here. I enjoyed this film very much, and I recommend it highly.

title: The Social Network
review: The Social Network is a biographical film based on the founder of Facebook – Mark Zuckerberg's experience. Beside Mark Zuckerberg as the hero, other main characters include Eduardo Saverin, Sean Parker and the Winklevoss brothers. The present timeline in the movie was an accusation from Eduardo and the Winklevoss to Zuckerberg. Narration about how Facebook was invented and developed was interspersed with flashbacks. The movie depicted the hero as a humorous genius at the beginning process but a friendship- traitor in the end of the story (i.e. in the present timeline).
