The movie was outstanding not only because of its unique narrating structure, but also due to its objective perspective about the person. The movie directly reveal the immoral side of Zuckerberg who was generally considered as a successful, gifted young entrepreneur. Except the complete delineation of the hero, the supporting roles are absolutely perfectly and logically portrayed. The simple and devoting Eduardo, the guileful Sean with a brain of business and single-minded Winklevoss. The betrayal, deceit and interavailability in the characters' friendship finally torn apart the fragile image of harmony.

title: No one said superiority would be easy
review: The single minded determination demonstrated by the main character is a wonderful example of what it takes to achieve revolutionary creations. Ignoring lesser minds is simply a matter of turning the volume of your mind down when dealing with the ideas and opinions of the fear based rigid masses. Zuckerberg reminds me of Jobs. They both just steamroll past the weakness of others. The scene where MZ verbally slaps and experienced lawyer is brilliant. It takes a lot of courage to go toe to toe with older generations when you have been conditioned to believe that they deserve respect. Respect is earned. MZ has mine. If you study either MZ or Jobs and find them arrogant and selfish; it is safe to categorize yourself as food for the wolves. Fear not. Good company is found in the herd.

title: Great film progression
review: I think that its a great movie because I like how the story progresses and how the film is shot. However, I personally believe that the film's depiction of the characters are definitely an exaggeration to their real life situations, making it a little more of a fiction rather than an actual biography, which didn't really do the job of flabbergasting me in the way films based on real-life people are supposed to. This drama film also has a pretty decent sense of humour, adding a tinge of comedy into it. I guess I just really enjoy the formality of this movie. The twins in the movie - played by Armie Hammer - are too good looking.

title: Great Idea poor execution
review: The Social Network has a great story to tell about the rise of facebook and the journey Mark Zuckerberg made to get to where he is. I was very disappointed to find out that it wasn't about this, it was more about the dispute between Zuckerberg and his friend Eduardo Saverin. The story the movie tells about the creation of facebook is, to my dismay, littered with fiction. It felt like the director based the character of Zuckerberg not based on the original but on a slightly different version of Zuckerberg who is a insecure and asinine genius. They portray his character this way by changing a few things about the real story of Zuckerberg. In reality Mark Zuckerberg is none of these things and the portrayal of him in the movie is so far off from reality it hurts. Aside from this flaw the movies main focus as far as plot is not the rise of facebook and the different challenges the team face but the relationship between Mark and Eduardo. In fact the movie is almost entirely about their feud. This makes sense, seeing as how the movie is based off the book The Accidental Billionaires: The Founding of Facebook: A Tale of Sex, Money, Genius and Betrayal. A book that tells the story of how facebook was created without any help from the creator of facebook himself Mark Zuckerberg. Instead the author received a lot of help from the friend of Mark's who only funded the project Eduardo. It's frustrating how to think that they would make a movie after such a crappy book but there really isn't much we can do about it now. In conclusion, I wish this movie had never been made 0 stars

title: The Social Network (2010) is a biographical drama by American director David Fincher, starring Jesse Eisenberg, Andrew Garfield, Justin Timberlake and Rooney Mara.
review: I could say that I am a big fan of David Fincher's work. I have seen all of his best work – Fight Club (1999), Se7en (1995), Gone Girl (2014), The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008) and Zodiac (2007). Three of them are my favorite films of all time. A lot of his films have won Oscars or have been nominated for one. The Social Network tells a story about Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg, who creates the social media site, which nowadays we know as Facebook, but is later sued by two brothers, who claimed he stole their idea, and the co- founder who was later pushed out of the business. I really liked the film, although I saw it the first time few years ago after it had came out. I liked it because it was so inspiring that after watching it, I wanted to go and do something creative on my own. I liked that it was really dramatic, it was a true drama, the main character went thru hell but in the end (almost) everything was fine. I like that it shows the struggles of teenagers life – the difficulties in student life , how hard is university and how hard you need to work to get what you want. It shows what is the actual price to make a company that ears millions. There's no other film like this, that is why it is so special.

title: The Social Network
review:
The story is about a man start up the Facebook that many people uses in the world. He is a university student and a skilled programmer, but he is hard to deal with people. By a chance that he breaks up his girlfriend, he tried to create the cite of internet that ranking women student. The site records enormous accesses and his name becomes widely known around his university. The event is an origin of Facebook. However, it has also a lot of troubles. He faces hardship to protect the site.

The film has dialogue and colors. The genre of this movie is biography and drama. It has sound effect and it is useful to enter the world of drama. I think that it is easy to understand because I am familiar with social network system and I make use of Facebook. In addition, it is good that a pace of the story goes smoothly.

title: An undeniable masterpiece
review: David Fincher has stunned me again with "The Social Network". I saw the DVD cover several months ago and I thought that it would be just an abysmal attempt at making a good film. Then I saw Fincher's name and I had second thoughts. I bought and watched it that day and I applauded it after the viewing. I had never seen a biopic that interesting! This could be the only film featuring that sodding Timberlake I truly enjoyed! It taught me that anyone can do great things if you put your mind to it. I was surprised this film didn't have a 15 as its UK certificate seeing as there is a considerable amount of profanity and drug use. There was a lot of tension in the scene in which Eduardo falls out with Mark but it is undoubtedly my favourite scene in the film. Great job, David!

title: Best Fincher movie
review: 'The Social Network' is a rare modern biographical movie that succeeds on almost every level possible with each character,scene etc. This movie has got everything that you would expect from a biographical drama with awesome screenplay by Aaron Sorkin and brilliant direction by David Fincher that keeps viewers hooked to the movie. A compelling lead performance by Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield and a great soundtrack that absolutely gets all along with the theme of the movie.This movie is so inspirational in its own terms and the common themes like friendship,ego,etc. have been portrayed effectively.David Fincher has been always consistent with his direction and he never fails to entertain.This movie is definitely awesome for repeated viewings.I have probably watched this movie more than 7 times and in every single viewing,it gets only better and better.This movie deserves a little higher rating in IMDb and a spot in top 250.

title: Great acting movie
review:
In some ways I do think this film was made a bit early. Facebook isn't that old a phenomenon, and thus a movie about its origins seems rushed as I don't think we have enough distance to view it objectively. That being said, David Fincher has pulled off some miracles here and I think this is about as perfect a movie about Facebook as was possible to be made. Some of its events and depictions can be argued with and you can definitely see that sometimes things are stretched in the name of drama, but as a story it works really well and will definitely give you some perspective on the web page most of us have come to rely on.

And at the centre of it all is Mark Zuckerberg played by Jesse Eisenberg in probably his best role performance so far. Zuckerberg is a great character. From the very first scene, where he's talking with his college girlfriend, you get this guy. He's a genius and in his case it's also a burden, a curse. He's in a constant state of frustration because to him everyone else seems to be moving in slow-motion. Everyone is always one or two steps behind and he has to slow done to let them catch up.

The movie deals with Zuckerberg's days in college while he was getting Facebook off the ground and with the legal battles that he had to go through later because everyone tried to stake their claim on the pot of gold he had founded. The movie is good at not taking sides and showing that while Zuckerberg certainly did some slightly questionable things, it's not like the other side was completely in the right either.

All in all The Social Network is worth a watch because it has great actors lead by a great director and the subject matter is something we're all familiar with and know personally. Best film of the year? Probably not, but it's up there.

title: Quickie Review: The Social Network
review:
Here is another David Fincher movie that I enjoyed watching but ultimately was left rather indifferent. The bromance between best friends Zuckerberg (Jessy Eisenberg) and Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Gardfield) is what drives this story of Facebook's creation – allegedly stolen by Zuckerberg from Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss (played by the same guy – wow! I couldn't tell at all). The much- raised dialogue in the movie was good but maybe a bit too much, as sometimes multiple sentences are stuffed into a scene that end up rendering it lifeless. You get the sense that the filmmakers are trying to make the scenes seem real and everyday-like, but I don't think they quite pulled it off.

For a film that's pretty relevant to today's users of social media the story is pretty by-the-numbers. I feel that the story of Facebook's creator is still going, and the movie was ended (or even made) prematurely. Even so, the subject matter doesn't really interest me much. If nothing else The Social Network shows just how sad, lonely and artificial you can become when surrounded by modern technology. That's what I thought of the protagonist anyway, since it seems the director wanted to show him as some misunderstood and sympathetic character. That, or he actually admires him?

Best Scene: I somewhat enjoyed the legal proceedings towards the end of the film and the feisty interactions between the once-friends

title: Betrayal, Revenge, Ambition, Greed and the Internet.
review: The Social Network (2010) Reviewed by Martin Davis. Retrospect Film on Facebook. Emerging in the 90's as one of Hollywood's most exciting talents, David Finchers' decision to direct 'The Social Network' seemed an unusual one to many at the time. The man who had brought us 'Se7en' and 'Fight Club' was now going to take on what some were dismissively calling "The Facebook movie". 'The Social Network' is, in reality, much less a film about the creation of Facebook and much more about the age old themes of betrayal, revenge, ambition and greed. The opening scene sets the tone perfectly. It is late 2003 and Harvard University student and computer genius Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) is being dumped by his girlfriend. It is clear from Eisenberg's portrayal and Aaron Sorkins' distinctively brilliant dialogue that this is not the most likable of leading men, yet somehow, as the film progresses we find ourselves rooting for him. Returning to his dorm Zuckerberg writes a spiteful entry on his blog about his ex and then creates a website called 'Facemash' by hacking into the college databases and stealing photos of female students to allow site visitors to rate their attractiveness. After causing the Harvard servers to crash Zukerberg is given six months academic probation. The fuse has been lit though and inadvertently he has caught the attention of several influential figures, most notably the Winklevoss twins and their business partner Divya Narendra who approach him with their idea for a social media site. With financial backing from his best friend Eduardo Savarin, Zuckerberg creates what he calls 'thefacebook'. With his business partners kept in the dark about its launch, a bitter legal wrangle ensues. The courtroom scenes are interspersed throughout the film and having relocated to California and cut his ties with Savarin, Zuckerberg and his team watch the newly renamed 'Facebook' grow in strength, culminating in its first one million members. Eisenberg is excellent as Zukerberg, a young man consumed with ruthless ambition and not prepared to let anything stand in his way. Superbly scripted, directed and acted, the film defied all preconceptions and was a success both critically and at the box office, going on to win three academy awards and three Baftas. Recommended. Martin Davis. Retrospect Film on Facebook.

title: An Average Movie
review: The movie is a story of Facebook founder Mark and how the "Facebook" has become possible after the "the Facebook". After watching the movie the image of Mark Zuckerberg is tarnished (according to the story in the movie),though later Mark Zuckerberg expressed his disagreement with the story. Andrew Garfield again proved his skills,Jesse too played his role nicely but it was Andrew who stole the limelight.The movie revolves around the court and the college and facebook life for the Mark.All the actors were great with their roles.In the movie the character Mark Zuckerberg inspired me by his hard-work and dedication,his creativity and decision making skills and ideas.But ,the movie has shown the other side of him as unfriendly ,deceitful and rude,his unaccepted behaviour towards his girlfriend when she broke-up with him.The movie has shown us the truth of life in Silicon valley.But it was just an average movie,and not good for Zuckerberg's fan :P.

title: Interesting
review:
If I had to sum up "The Social Network" in just a few words, I would probably say, "It's an interesting movie about an unlikable man". At least, that's the impression the filmmakers seem to have about Mark Zuckerberg. Though to their credit, they don't completely portray Zuckerberg as unlikable - he is shown to be socially awkward, among other things. I can personally relate to that trait myself. That's one of the many interesting things to be found in this movie. Other things include showing how the world of business can be a cutthroat game, where friendship and loyalty sometimes don't mean a darn.

The movie isn't perfect - though then again, few movies are. I would have liked to have been given a little background on Zuckerberg - we learn nothing about his past. Some of the technical jargon is a little hard to follow if you know little to nothing about computers (or Facebook, for that matter.) Also, the second half of the movie does have some lengthy portions that run a little slow (though they don't get to be downright boring.) All the same, the praise this movie has received is definitely worthy.

title: Strikingly, Electrically Modern- Fincher's Best
review:
I love David Fincher. I love his style, his cinematic poise; and, above all, what he represents. He is the walking, talking counterpoint to anyone who says film was better 'back in the day.' He uses modern sensibilities and techniques to tell modern stories.

Okay. Author interruption over. I'm not here to talk about what Fincher represents. I'm here to talk about what I believe to be the crowning film in his multi-jeweled golden crown. This film, The Social Network, is about one of the defining men of the twenty-first century, Mark Zuckerberg. It is not a straight historical retelling, of which I am mercifully glad. If the so-called historical purists had their way, this film would a snore. There are some people whose factual life stories make for good film; the subject of my last review, General George S. Patton, is one of them.

Mark Zuckerberg is not. Other than the fact that he founded a multi billion-dollar company, his life would hardly make for a better story than would mine. Granted, that is a big 'other', but still; he does not have grand tales of drama and adventure. This is not helped by the fact that he is, at the time of this piece's writing (Nov 11, 2015- Veterans Day), only 31. None of this is a knock on the man who I believe to be the living, breathing representation of why, despite it's many, many faults, I love the country that I live in. He is, in fact, an idol of mine. But his life still would not make an interesting movie told straight-up.

That's where Fincher comes in. Okay, not just Fincher; the film's writer, one Aaron Sorkin, deserves a lot of the credit too. As does Jesse Eisenburg, the actor who plays Zuck; despite looking nothing like the billionaire, he is convincing and emotive and a strong conduit; if he was bad, this film would not work. But he is, and it does.

As a self-proclaimed expert on titles, I can say that this film has a good one. Consider that they could have easily just named it 'Zuck' or 'Zuckerberg' or 'Mark Zuckerberg' or 'Facebook' or another one of the standard biopic titles, and did not; something that fits the fact that this film is decidedly not a straight biopic, as I have repeatedly mentioned. But it didn't just avoid being standard; it was great; again, like the movie.

The title of the book that this film was based on was 'The Accidental Billionaires.' I'm not going to pretend that's not a good a title; it is. It shows how success just rushed up on these guys like a rushing tsunami, leaving them to deal with the consequences. But the film is titled better, tackling a larger scope. I can't go two feet or two seconds nowadays without hearing the words 'Social Network' or 'Social Media' or something of that sort. But Facebook isn't just 'a social network'. It is 'The Social Network.' Everyone who came after Zuck has been living in his shadow, and perhaps they always will. He pushed the world onward like few others of the past few decades, and the title reflects that.

Many people (well, some; this movie does have a ninety-six percent rating on Rotten Tomatoes and will be on many best of the decade lists) have a problem with what they consider to be simple characterization of Zuckerberg. I would not quite say that this is a nothing complaint, but I do think that it was expanded greatly by people just seeing what they want to see. Zuckerberg has built with his hands and mouse one of the largest and most successful startups ever; I think he has a right to be a little defensive and aggressive. I know I would be. No, the real Zuckerberg is probably not like this. And if you're in the wrong mood, it could get a bit on one's nerves. But I think this is a primary case of people not checking their personal moralities and beliefs at the door and embracing the art, as you should every time you're watching a good movie. Remember this point; I will bring it up again when I review Amelie.

Anyway, the soundtrack is subtle, the visual style captures the tone and subject matter of the film perfectly, and the script is tight enough. The dialogue is sharp and on point because of course it is, it's a Sorkin film. There are a lot of blues in the film, making it look visually striking. But even if you don't prefer style over substance like I do, don't worry. There is enough in the film for you too. it has a certain way of blowing you away while keeping your feet on the ground.

The narrative arc for this film is incredible. You feel every high and every low, and at the end, you are right there with Zuckerberg, wondering how it has all come to this. It is an introspective and contemplative film, one that evokes on an artistic level, a philosophical level, and an entertainment level. Inception may be my favorite film of this decade, but if there is one that I believe to be indicative of everything worthwhile from it... this movie would be right up there in consideration. Go see it if you haven't.

(P.S. The biggest surprise for me when watching this was how good JT was. He is a good actor when cast properly.) (P.P.S. In case you're wondering, yes, I do believe this film was screwed out of Best Picture because Oscar voters are a bunch of old white men who probably have no clue what a 'face-book' is.)

title: Slow-Paced but Still a Good Movie
review:
I went into this movie with pretty high hopes. Considering I'd just watched a handful of great movies with lower user scores and higher metascores, and I thought I'd love this one just as much as those. It was a lot slower than I expected, but it may have felt that way due to the fact that I started watching it at midnight.

The Social Network is a pretty interesting movie. It follow the guy, Mark Zuckerberg, who created facebook and all the problems that occur during and after this process. It's well made, and the plot is interesting. As someone who uses facebook a fair amount, it was interesting to see who made it (I know it wasn't Jesse Eisenberg, don't worry) and how it was made.

The characters were the primary driving force in the movie it seemed. Jesse Eisenberg, as usual, played a great nerdy character who doesn't seem to understand human emotion that well. It's a typical role for him, but he does it extremely well. As for everyone else, they were all interesting characters who change throughout the movie, making it feel a lot more realistic. Although it is a biography so of course it's expected to be realistic.

Overall The Social Network is a solid movie. With great acting and interesting characters and plot, it's worth a watch. It wasn't as great as some of the previous movies I've watched lately, and it was definitely a slower paced movie, but it's still good. If your interested, give it a watch. It's worthwhile. If you didn't enjoy it, then that's okay, I can see why. In the end I probably would recommend it, but maybe only to people whom I think would like it.

title: Disappointing
review:
I'm not sure just what I was expecting, but it wasn't this. The DVD cost $5, for a two-disc set! I watched disc 1 last year, rated it a 2 and wrote in my journal - "can't be bothered to see the bonus features". Is that fair? So, now I've seen disc two, and rated that a 2 also (and wrote the only (so far) review), then disc one again and then again to get the director's commentary.

OK, the acting is good, Eisenberg looks and sounds like Zuckerberg. But Zuckerberg is portrayed as clever, ruthless, manipulating, unscrupulous, devious, unpleasant, dishonest, disloyal ... and yet, he hasn't sued! So, is it accurate? That is not my impression of Mark. (from all sources, not personal of course). Time magazine's Person of the Year for 2010 was Zuckerberg and they were writing the story as the movie was released, and it is mentioned a couple of times in what is otherwise a real hagiography. Zuckerberg's only comment is to question their representation for the motivation for the whole idea of Facebook.

But the article doesn't mention the names Winklevoss or Saverin once. Not really a surprise? Here is my advice. Watch the first scene (which took 99 takes to get!), but be warned, you will have to turn the subtitles on, otherwise you'll miss half what is babbled. This must be the worst ever first scene of a movie? Then go to Scene Selection and go to #15 (the second to last) by then Facebook is flying and they go past the 1 million members, it is a huge success. But then we learn that the lawsuit that has occupied most of the scenes from #2-#14 is to be settled out of court and it involves the payment by Zuckerberg or Facebook, of a HUGE sum and another, the details of which remain a secret but is even HUGER.

There are times when I was really impressed by the production, and there are some good little scenes, but overall, it leaves a bad memory, and nearly all lawsuit films are *boring*.

title: The Social Network isn't a story based movie with assertive plot like Se7en
review: Actually I have been a member of facebook since 2009. When I heard for the first time that one of my favorite directors, David Fincher, is going to make a movie based on facebook's story, I was wondering "what kind of interesting point Fincher sees in this!" It could be a boring movie without any sign of excitement we used to see in his previous movies. By the way he proved that I was wrong! This is on of his best movies and I'm glad that Fincher successfully turned this typical story into some valuable narratives. The Social Network isn't a story based movie with assertive plot like Se7en, but I can say it's a plot-based movie. There are some young people coming up with an idea, making a website which gathers people together in a limited range of places, Harvard university in the first place. As Mark Zukerberg says in the movie -You don't get 500 million friends without making a few enemies- Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg), founder of the website, finds himself disputing with some people including his best friend Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Garfield). The movie goes forward very well. The main story happens in a court in which the history of founding of the website is told in flashbacks. All the scenes, present and past, are related perfectly that face you with a pleasant story until its very end. You may don't like villains of the movie –Winklevoss brothers- because of course they are not the second version of a eloquent serial killer like John Doe, but I'm sure they are in the best place they could ever be, however it depends on your standpoint whether like them or not because they are just some inept geek university students. Fincher with The Social Network proves that you don't necessarily need to have a criminal story to keep the viewers up to the screen, and he also proves that even most commonplace events can be complicated deep inside.

title: David Fincher the master
review: When i heard that Fincher directed the movie about Facebook i was disappointed.I just couldn't imagine that Fincher would be interested in a story like that one...so i watch the movie after few years and...yes..he did it again..he pulled the strings where they need to be pulled...like puppet master. Also,Sorkins writing is great and actors are really good... I don't like this virtual world much and my man Fincher shows all the downfalls of living in one. Great movie about the soul less world. There was no much room for camera and other effects to be a big part of this movie and Fincher know that and instead he concentrates on a story and yes ..he did great job again.Good decision to watch this movie after so long because im not disappointed.

title: A tale of an achiever, driven by desire, marked by triumph, tainted by unfaithfulness.
review: It did take me quite a long time since the release to enjoy this lovely piece of work by David Fincher. Knowing David for his style of storytelling was in fact the reason that made me to sit & give this movie a try. Looking into any biography movie or any other movie that is based on a true story so far, one could definitely point out the flaws on the storyline or the casting choices. Yet accepting the challenge of doing such a movie is what differentiates such directors from other. The casting of the movie does needs to be given a special appreciation as they bought all the real life characters into life, especially bringing in some of the youngest talents in the business such as Jesse Eisenberg, Andrew Garfield, Justin Timberlake & Armie Hammer. The movie opens with a couple in a crowded college bar and ends with a man alone in a room repeatedly hitting refresh on his laptop soon after a friend request. In between, David and Sorkin offer up a creation story for the digital age and something of a morality tale, one driven by desire, marked by triumph, tainted by unfaithfulness and inspired by the new gospel: the geek shall inherit the earth.

title: This is only the beginning.
review:
Social media. It dominates our everyday lives. We can barely remember a time when we weren't glued to our phones, or even when "phone" wasn't a ubiquitous term for "cell phone," or when "cell phone" wasn't an antiquated term for "iPhone" or "Smartphone." Sites like Twitter, YouTube, and foursquare (or Swarm) comprise the majority of our everyday online experiences.

It was Facebook that took it to a level no one could have possibly predicted.

With the creation of Facebook, *everyone* had a chance to view each other's lives in a way that was not previously conceptualized. Or was. That's what this film is about. The lawsuits that arose after Facebook's founding was called into legal question makes for thrice-Oscar- nominated cinema that is paralleled by no other. Now connecting upwards of 1/7th of humanity, Facebook has given rise to people and organizations previously unthinkable in that Harvard dorm room straight out of A Beautiful Mind.

But this is only the beginning.

As President and Head Administrator of the Facebook group Future Presidents of the United States, and having been contacted by the White House thanks to my efforts, I can safely say that Mr. Zuckerberg, Mr. Severin, and countless other individuals responsible for the creation and upkeep of Facebook have not yet fully realized the scope and scale of what they have unleashed upon the world.

The intersection of history and technology has been demonstrated to change the course of humanity throughout various eras. I think it's safe to say that this is the beginning of one of those eras. Though Facebook turned 11 this past February, it's only in its infancy. Where will it be at 20? 30? 50? 100? The Internet and Cyberspace in general won't be going anywhere anytime soon. Democracy and politics in general won't be going anywhere anytime soon. How will Facebook and the Internet in general change the landscape to make way for the most technologically-literate generation the world has ever seen, Generation Y, to not only take the reigns of power, but to *keep* the reigns of power?

It appears to me that in my many platforms of research that Millennials are somewhat of a novelty. We seem to be stuck in a kind of Purgatory, neither advancing on the world stage, nor shrinking away from it. There is no one central figure among us who we can point to and say, "That's who we are. That person represents us."

That person will more than likely come from Facebook.

Not necessarily the founders, not necessarily its current architects, but one of us. One of its members. And no, not necessarily me, either. I'm not looking to gain publicity for the sake of gaining publicity. I'm just looking to set myself apart from the crowd and call attention to a number of issues facing not only my generation, but the generations that will depend on us to receive the passing of the torch. The coherency of the message is lost in the roar of the crowd. People have to be willing to make themselves vulnerable and stand up for what is right. Alone. And in this hyper-connected day and age, that's not something many people are willing, or even able, to do.

But I am.

I am one of many. I am not alone. I have made it my professional intention to look ahead and ponder the long-term future of not only Facebook, but the Internet in general. This second dimension of humanity isn't going anywhere anytime soon. Neither is Facebook. It is *essential* in the everyday lives of *billions.*

It all started in a Harvard dorm room.

Look for sequels to this movie. There are a *lot* more to come.

title: Not just a film about Facebook
review:
Making a film based on the creation of something which is in a sense 'invisible' is challenging. But Fincher's impressive The Social Network is less about the popular website itself and more about the people involved in its creation and subsequent popularity growth.

The film opens smack-dab in the middle of a conversation in a bar between soon-to-be Facebook 'inventor' Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) and his girlfriend Erica Albright (Rooney Mara). Erica, eventually fed up with Mark's desire to attain status, breaks up with him. Mark, enraged, starts posting degrading comments about Erica and women in general on his blog. He also creates a website called "Facemash" where Harvard students can rate women based on their 'hotness'. The website becomes massively popular the very same night and causes Harvard's severs to crash, which for a 'computer geek' like Zuckerberg is an achievement rather than a problem. Two other students, the Winklevoss brothers, are impressed and recruit Mark to create a website focused on social interaction. Mark, however, takes their idea, adds things and creates his own website behind the Winklevoss' backs, called "The Facebook". The film then proceeds to go back and forth in time to show both the (legal) drama that is to come and the current evolution in popularity of "The Facebook".

One of the film's highlights is the quick-witted script by The West Wing creator Aaron Sorkin. For those who say the script feels unnatural, I can only refer you to Network, a film made about 30 years ago, known for its brilliant and yes, unnatural screenplay, that is still talked about to this day. Anyway, there's not much to say about the script that hasn't been said already: it's occasionally 'tech-y' but not too much, clever, smart and lightning-fast, something the film's fantastic editing emphasizes (the first time I felt I had a chance to catch my breath was during a rowing match somewhere halfway in the film!). Fincher's direction believably places the viewer in the college experience, showing glimpses of parties, classes and the oppressive college culture lying underneath it all where financial success is everything. Fincher also deserves a lot of credit for coaxing uniformly excellent performances from such a young cast. The extras present on the special edition reveal how Fincher spent weeks around the table with the actors, endlessly discussing the characters.

A film like this, based on historical events, will always be partially judged on how well it stays true to the very history it attempts to recreate. I have doubts whether The Social Network follows everything down to the smallest details, but I always saw the film more as a social commentary. Fincher seemed to have a strong interest in the moral degradation underlying the character's world and actions. This is something Fincher is more than familiar with, having explored similar issues in films like Se7en, The Game and Fight Club and (his next film) The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.

It's interesting to note in hindsight the battle between The King's Speech and The Social Network at the Oscars. While The Social Network had been dominating the awards season up to the BAFTA's, the Academy went with The King's Speech in the end, awarding it Best Picture and Best Director among others. Why this sudden change? There are a number of reasons, two of which are the most popular: 1) The King's Speech checked more boxes in the so-called 'award bait' category (disease/disability, British Royalty, overcoming the odds) and 2) it captured the 'hearts' of the Academy. People expected voters to vote with their hearts than with their minds. In other words, The King's Speech was the more likable film. I'll end this review with a quote from the ending to The Social Network that, in retrospect, captures this sentimentalism:

MARYLIN I'm talking about a jury. I specialize in voir dire--jury selection. And what the jury sees when they look at the defendant. Clothes, hair, speaking style, likability—

MARK Likability?

MARYLIN I've been licensed to practice law for all of 20 months and I could get a jury to believe you planted the story about Eduardo and the chicken. Watch what else. Why weren't you at Sean's sorority party that night?

MARK You think I'm the one who called the police?

MARYLIN Doesn't matter. I asked the question and now everybody's thinking about it. You've lost your jury in the first 10 minutes.

Note that Mark says 'Likability?' in a mocking manner, showing he already knows he's not the most charismatic guy around. Also, replace the word 'jury' with 'Oscar voters' in that last sentence and you see why The Social Network lost its chances at the Best Picture Oscar in the first 10 minutes.

title: Time to learn about the pioneer of real Social Network
review: Eisenberg was at his best !! The acting was total class . The adaptation was noteworthy! Its not easy to adapt such a film with such a confusing story line. But there are times when u don't quite understand what's actually going . But overall the movie is a kind of must watch.Other people also did a good work especially Andrew Garfield ,he was my favourite all the time. Those who liked JOBS the biopic of Steve Jobs will definitely like this one.went into this film with little or no hope. By the time the movie was over, with the Beatles' "Baby, You're A Rich Man" playing over the end credits, I had a huge smile on my face. I literally cannot wait to watch this again during it's wide release.How the real Mark Zuckerberg was ? What was his Company? Did he had a girlfriend? ...to knw all this ,The Social Network is a must watch!!!!!

title: excellently directed and acted out film!
review:
First off I'm not going to go into how close to real life this film is (or isn't) and how much is true or not because I just don't know and am not too fussed to be honest the little I did tho I thought they did very well and ill be speaking about the film not how close it was to real life and all the rest of it.

The social network is all about Mark Zuckerberg and how he invented Facebook and becoming the youngest billionaire in history. This film shows how he got there and the success and complications in doing so.

First off I loved this film as a daily user of Facebook I was intrigued to see how it all started for Mark. First off I loved how this film was directed it was a joy to watch the cut scenes between the court room discussions and how they got to said court room discussions was beautifully done. The casting was nothing short of perfect now I'm going to give some credit to David Fincher for this but Jesse Eisenberg played Mark Zuckerberg so incredibly well you really believed he was a genus who was a bit of a loner, in just how he would presented himself. To make him likable, understandable and at the same time make you realise he wasn't perfect and was at times an ass hole, is one of the biggest compliments i can give to somebody who is playing a character like this, in a film like this. One of the biggest things people didn't like about the film Jobs is that it idealised the main guy too much, made him perfect when he wasn't how could anybody be after becoming that successful. So too see that so brilliantly done in this film is a massive highlight for me. Since this film Andrew Garfield is well known for his Spider-Man role and i thought going back to this film would make me just see him as spider-man but i was wrong he immersed himself into the role and you really understand why he's upset at least i did. I was pleasantly surprised at how good Justin Timberlake was in the film he really sold the character and the fact i didn't like him shows that he did a really good job. A quick note to the man who played the lawyer for Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss he was perfect something about his voice and how he produced his lines really made me feel that this was a proper lawsuit and it was much more serious than it seemed. This takes me to the script which was magnificently done. Overall I really enjoyed this film a lot and thought it was an interesting film that was excellently directed and acted out. A solid 8/10

title: The Social Network- the best film of all time?
review:
David Fincher has directed many thrilling and perceptive films in the past; however his latest film can be seen as his best work yet.

Fincher doesn't just explore the obvious ideas of personal theft, violation, contradiction and inhuman endeavors; we are taken inside the minds of Zuckerberg, we are taken into this world of social manipulation and categorization and we are inadvertently left creeping behind the door yearning to identify more of what our societies future offers.

Facebook is used as a tool to portray mistrust, connection and denial. It explores this new wave of social media and technological connections, however the film really highlights our generations lack of human interaction and need to live inside their social conscience, unable to listen to their own.

title: Fictionalized but still fascinating portrait of a 21st-century phenomenon
review: Seems typical of our new century that a product whose original selling point was "exclusivity" is now being consumed by over a billion people. For once, Aaron Sorkin's turned out a script where the characters aren't a whole lot smarter and quicker and funnier than any group of people could possibly be (cf. The West Wing, The Newsroom). His portrait of Mark Zuckerberg as a geeky outsider who can't relate to women may not have much to do with the real MZ— ex- captain of the Exeter fencing team who's been in a stable relationship since his sophomore year in college—but Jesse Eisenberg does a great job reimagining him as a remote, high-functioning sociopath who keeps his eyes on the prize at all times. Justin Timberlake does even better as Sean Parker, the Napster bad boy, who made sure that the Facebook stayed cool and didn't sell too many ads for the Harvard bartending course. Haven't seen 'em all, but this one seems like Fincher's best since Fight Club. And not to worry too much about Eduardo and the Winklevii (pitch-perfect performances, btw)—looks like they all managed to land on their feet somehow...

title: A masterpiece
review:
I watched this movie for the 7th time today because because Gone girl is coming out next week. And once again I was struck by just how good this movie is. Wonderful acting, excellent directing, beautiful cinematography, incredibly sharp editing and an amazing screenplay.

The movie opens with Mark Zuckerberg, the creator of Facebook talking to his girlfriend Erica in a bar. At the end of the conversation Erica breaks up with Mark. From this starts the story of the birth of Facebook. The story is told through flashbacks while Zuckerberg is going through two lawsuits: one from the Winkelvoss twins, from whom Zuckerberg might or might not have stolen Facebook and one from his former best friend and the co-founder of Facebook, Eduardo Saverin. In the flashbacks we follow birth and rise of Facebook.

The script of this movie is amazing. It's easily the best script in years. The dialog is smart and fast, just what you would expect from the film's writer Aaron Sorkin. Mark is an interesting and layered character but he's not a nice guy. The script is actually full of mean and annoying characters and that's quite shocking because everyone else would like to tell the heroic story of how young Zuckerberg created the great Facebook. But Sorkin doesn't. He's not interested in that. Perhaps none of these guys are good but they're interesting and through these characters Sorkin tells a much more important and interesting story. The movie has themes that don't have anything to do with Facebook so it doesn't matter if you don't care about Facebook. I actually personally hate Facebook and think this is a great movie. Because this movie is not about Facebook.

The movie is of course about human relationships. All that Mark wants in the end is to have friends. He is someone who has almost no friends (pretty much only one) and he is not a nice guy. He is rude to everybody and he doesn't even notice it. He wants to be someone like Sean Parker, someone who has friends and still can say exactly what he wants. But even Sean can't do that even though he looks like that is exactly what he does. And in this play of wanting to be powerful and get friends he actually loses the one person who he could actually call his friend. He has surrounded himself now with people who aren't his friends but just people who act like they like him. And he is not happy about that because he knows that these people aren't his friends. So he tries to connect Erica, the one person who has been his friend and who he cares about that might be able to forgive him and who is probably the most honest and caring person he knows.

The performances are wonderful. Andrew Garfield is really good as Eduardo but the movie's best performance is easily Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg. He is excellent in every single scene he is in. The way he performs Sorkin's incredibly fast dialog is amazing and he also knows how to perform the quieter scenes.

But this movie wouldn't have been nearly as good as it is without David Fincher. He knows exactly what he wants from every scene and he goes and does it. Every scene is masterfully made and the feeling of the movie is really interesting.

Fincher also hired a lot of great artists to work on the technical aspects of the movie. The editing by Kirk Baxter and Angus Wall is close to perfect, Jeff Cronenworth's cinematography is excellent and Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross's score is extremely good.

I watched the movie for the first time when it came out in 2010 and I hated it. I thought that it was boring and Zuckerberg was annoying. And when Mark betrays Eduardo I became really angry at him because the only character I really cared about was Eduardo. Now I've grown up a bit and understand and appreciate the movie. The social network is a great movie and one of the best movies of the 2010s so far.

title: A film for my generation?
review:
Looking through the reviews on this site, it's hard to really add anything new about The Social Network. It's brilliant. I can hardly fault it. However, I am a serious Facebook addict (currently undergoing electric shock treatment to help myself cut down) so it fascinated me to hear about the back story as to how it was created, who owned it (and who nearly owned it).

I would rate this 9/10 – great performances, great direction (David Fincher, I now officially forgive you for your part in Alien 3) and great pace.

So, as an experiment and, in keeping with my 9/10 rating, I invited my Mum and Dad round to watch it. The second time around I enjoyed it as much as the first. In short, when I asked my parents to rate it out of 10, they gave it a 5 and a 6. They didn't get it. They didn't understand Facebook, or "the fuss" about it. They didn't understand anything more technical than the term "the web" and they found all the characters unlikeable and annoying. Only a few hours after the credits rolled and my Mum was having difficulty remembering anything other than people were generally moaning at each other over something that involved money.

I guess if you're one of the stereotypical 'Facebook generation' you may love this. If not, stick with your knitting (and, no, my Mum will never read this).

I'm now off to cut and paste this whole review to my status – please feel free to comment :oD

http://thewrongtreemoviereviews.blogspot.co.uk/

title: a story how Facebook began
review:
Through watching this film, I can understand how the Facebook started; however, I was slightly shocked because the reason Mike established this system in Harvard University wasn't good. It's kind of ranking system. As for me, his action wasn't permissive. Anyway, he's a clever business man considering everything. As the advertisement says, "you don't get to 500 million friends without making a few enemies". This message represents his way to promote his company, I suppose. We might not be able to get everything in order to make a great success.

Jesse Eisenberg, who plays Mark Zuckerberg, mimics Mark's way to speak. He speaks so fast that I cannot follow all of his lines.

title: SNSInfoTech.SG is the best SEO Company in Singapore
review:
I must to say the Social Network is an almost perfect film that packages the early 21st century version of the American Dream in a simple and engaging morality tale.

One new star SNSInfoTech.SG is the best SEO Services Company in Singapore, which one provide the premium Search Engine Optimization services, web design services, email marketing services.

And the Social Network is very well directed. F directs with an intensity and focus that makes The Social Network tied with Seven as the best of his movies in my eyes. Another strong point is the screenplay which is very smart and sharp, while the story making the most of this intriguing concept is constantly snappy and engaging.

title: The Social Network: Is it discouraging?
review:
While clearly written with a stress on the importance of the hyperbolic idiosyncrasies that define the main character Zuckerburg, the script was also tastefully crafted with underlying, witty humor that was carefully sculpted into something that could get a chuckle from the audience while maintaining the authenticity of the events. This combination of heavily intellectualized prose and the aforementioned dry comedy made for an efficient, yet subtly entertaining film.

The one genuinely overlooked part of this picture that many have failed to assess as a failure is simply the ending. While seeing Zuckerburg refresh again and again in hopes that his old girlfriend will accept his friend request shows the audience that the road to success does not come without lost connections (as mentioned in the film's production poster), it is clear that his success is inspirational and should be mirrored by many young entrepreneurs in today's society. My fear is that with this notion of the creation of enemies, it will discourage the pursuance of dreams and ultimately eliminate any future successful entrepreneurs.

title: a nice bio
review: "The social network" the story of how the youngest ever billioner Mark Zuckerberg created facebook when he was in college and how it effected his life until the legal negotiations against his formal partners. As a biography, or part of it, the movie is great, with the story shifting from the past to the future, presenting the facts nicely and without confusing the audience. The performances are great too, especially Eisenberg as Zuckerberg and Garfield as Mark's best friend Eduardo Saverin. The characters are presented as they are, with their passions and flaws, without making them look as super humans, so that's a plus for the film. Finally the movie doesn't get boring, which is a relief, and there aren't many layers of depth, so there is very little food for thought. However, The social network is not a movie that entertains lot of people, and it is difficult to be watched again, as all you have to see, you can see them the first time. And that's why I am giving it 6 out of 10.

title: Its good, but what am I not getting here?
review:
Im not old by any stretch of the imagination. Im 17 years old and have had a Facebook account for about 4 years, I grew up with stories of Napster and Facebook in the news, this film interested me and, its good but, why do people consider this genius filmmaking.

The characters are all played very well by their respective actors. But the characters themselves I find hard to care about. There not the worst people in the world, there not the best either, so I don't really care if they succeed or not. The story itself, finding out how Facebook was created, is fairly interesting but thats practically wrapped up in the first 45 minutes, leaving the remainder of the film to wrap up how everyone ends up suing Mark Zuckerberg.

The film is good though. It may not sound like it from what iv said but, its good. Jesse Eisenberg is very good as Zuckerberg and although, like I said before, I found it hard to care for him as a person, it doesn't diminish the performance which is spot on as a social inept genius who wants everything, even if it means betraying everyone who's ever cared for him. I enjoyed seeing Zuckerberg strive for more from his company, shutting the outside world out, shutting his friends out and ultimately thats what lead to the lawsuits.

I really like the score too, its got this great ambiance that affects the entire film. It gives it this hip, here and now atmosphere that fits the tone and theme of the film perfectly. The films also perfectly shot, what else would you expect of David Fincher.

Overall, The Social Network is good, but disappointing. I expected another masterpiece from the man who directed Fight Club and Panic Room, but we got this instead, and i'm fine with it.

title: A fantastic showcase of brilliant acting
review: What makes The Social Network such a fantastic movie is the extraordinary performance of all the actors involved as well as the film's ability to have you rooting for every side. Jesse Eisenburg was a fantastic Zuckerburg and displayed how it truly feels to be a socially awkward nerd. In a not at all kiddish way, Zuckerburg simply wants to be cool. He does not found Facebook with the intent of being successful, he simply wants to be liked and superior. This film fantastically conveys this with moments such as the rejection of the idea to begin advertisements on Facebook because, though this would bring a large sum of money, it wasn't "cool". Zuckerburg constantly battles with his inability to connect with anyone outside of himself and others with his same motivation and in the end, it costs him his best friend and a small fortune. Andrew Garfield, for lack of a better description, is the standout actor of the film. The relatively unknown name of Eduardo Saverin would have remained as such had Garfield not given his character a personality that portrayed the view of the common man observing the passage at play. Throughout the film Saverin is used repeatedly by his best friend and finally discarded like a broken tool. Saverin provides the mood for the entire movie, being the comic relief in lighthearted scenes and demonstrating the anger and betrayal felt in the upsetting scenes. Though this movie is a success on many fronts, it does become noticeably less interesting in scenes in which the Winklevoss twins and Sean Parker were prevalent. This is not for lack of performance, but rather that the scenes were often unnecessary and irrelevant. For example, the scene in which Parker tells Zuckerburg about the founding of Victoria's Secret could have been completely erased with no negative repercussions. The same applies to the twins' meeting with Larry Summers. Despite these few flaws, this is a must watch movie in the age of technology that sheds light on the controversial introduction to one of the world's current most well-known companies around the world.

title: Deserving of every accolade
review:
In 1987 Oliver Stone produced a film that encapsulated a whole era and captured the Zeitgeist perfectly, the character of Gordon Gekko crystallising the most prevalent of the seven deadly sins of the time. In 2010 Stone is set on repeating this trick by attempting to pull off one of the hardest tasks in the film industry; the sequel that matches up to its predecessor. The timing seems perfect, with the current financial crisis reflecting the true bust of the late eighties boom and the impending release of the original film's central character in real time. However, his film has been eclipsed by The Social Network. As the seventies had All The President's Men, the eighties had Stone's aforementioned Wall Street, the nineties had The Insider and now, after a decade without a major time capsule of a film, the new millennium has The Social Network.

With The Social Network slamming Wall Street 2 at the box office it seems that while Stone has been missing the mark with presidential bio- pics and fumbling around South America stroking the egos of Bolivarian political leaders his position, that he earned cutting his teeth (or should that be grinding his teeth) working on Scarface, as the major socio-political-commentator-director has been usurped by a younger model in the form of David Fincher. Presenting the skills he has crafted and honed since his 1995 breakthrough picture Se7en, Fincher is backed by a killer script from The West Wing's Aaron Sorkin. It is testament to Sorkin's ability that he managed to pull it off. The facebook story is RAM full of absolutely un-writable characters. After all, if you were to conjure a pair of opponents for Zuckerberg upon the battlefield of intellectual property, would you have chosen identical twin Olympic rowers christened with the inimitable moniker of Winklevoss? I wouldn't imagine so. But, it is in characters such as these that some of the wittiest of dialogue comes; as one of the twins negates the need to hire someone for the job of intimidating facebook founder Mark Zuckerburg: "I'm 6'4, weigh 220 pounds and there's two of me."

Fincher has also assembled a great cast. A handful of the best young actors in America appear in this movie. Jesse Eisenberg's portrayal of the character is so deft and on point that we are treated to a mesmerising display that excels past even the usual high standard of performance Fincher manages to extract from his casts. He is ever unlikable, ever untrustworthy and ever petty, but does manage a small amount of sympathy in being that guy (we all know one), that brilliant, borderline genius without a clue. If Zuckerberg is truly anything like Eisenberg's version, then an argument for Asperger syndrome stands on firm footing. Andrew Garfield continues to impress, slightly twisting and improving his character and performance adeptly from the film Lions For Lambs earlier in the decade playing original facebook CFO Eduardo Saverin, I doubt, however, that the script, or demand on his acting ability, will match up to this role in the upcoming Spiderman movies. Despite these two lead characters portrayed so excellently, it is Justin Timberlake who shines as Napster founder Sean Parker. In a pivotal scene Parker sums up the ideology of today's intelligent and irreverent youth echoing Michael Douglas as Gordon Gekko giving the "greed is good" speech in 1987 verbally wrapping up the 80s yuppie mentality. I can smell the outside bet for Best Supporting Actor at next year's Oscars now. And I'm sure this will pick up a whole load of nominations elsewhere, and maybe some statuettes. Lord knows it deserves every accolade it receives. ********** (2010)

title: Hollywood-ized Docu-Drama
review: I really didn't have much interest in this movie until I saw that the screenplay was written by Aaron Sorkin and I have so far loved all things Sorkin (though I have so far been unconvinced by West Wing-ites to check that series out). Sorkin's work always centers on rapid-fire dialog and smartassery and this film has no shortage of either. From his media appearances I don't believe for a second that the real Mark Zuckerberg was as calm, "cool" and ruthless as portrayed by Jesse Eisenberg, but a nerdy portrayal wouldn't have worked in the film. On a scale of rewatchability, I can't say I'd go higher than 6/10, but for the superb acting and scripting, I must rate it higher. 8/10

title: David Fincher. What else?
review: David Fincher's work is truly remarkable. But the script is even better, incredibly written by Aaron Sorkin. It's just smart, funny and real. There was not even one useless dialogue. Everything they said was important and interesting. You feel you've known those characters for ages. And you're always wishing you could have been part of that project. Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield were amazing. Their flawless performances were one of the most important things that made this an exceptional film. Now, David Fincher... What can I say? He never fails. Never. After "Se7en", "Fight Club" and "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button", this is his well-deserved ticket into hall-of-fame greatness. All in all, "The Social Network" is a beautiful masterpiece, with an excellent soundtrack, that will allow you to know and get familiar with this amazing story: the creation of Facebook.

title: The social network
review:
The Social Network is a film describing the creation of Facebook. This film takes place at the University of Harvard were the student Mark Zuckenberg play by Jessie Eisenberg, creates Facebook just with his laptops and his impressive intellectual. This movie take us back to 2003 when Mark starts to study programing at Harvard. This movie helps us to understand all the secrets and problems it took to create the famous, Social Network.

Being the best programmer of your class seems pretty cool, but don't having friends is an exception; maybe it's the consequence of creating face Mach or crashing the web. Mark has his pros and cons characteristics but that didn't matter for the Winklevoss and their friend Divya Narrendra when they ask to Mark to create a special project of communication for Harvard. Mark accepted but he knew he had the ability to do something better, so Mark start to write codes for a special project he had in mind. We could see that Mark wasn't alone, he had his friend Eduardo that financed and sponsored his projects. The big problem begin when Sean Parker was contracted by Mark and when the brother Winklevoss and their friend heard about Mark project they knew they have to do something to confront him.

The social network has many incredible features, but out of doubt acting was the best from all. Jesse Eisenberg pictured himself as Mark Zuckenberg. He used to talk as a really intellectual guy making hard to gain a dispute against him. He always knew what to say, when to say it, and how to say it. He could also express the trait of leadership and how to be the alpha; he didn't let anyone to intimidate him or to take an advantage from him. Jesse Eisenberg did a great job as Mark Zuckenberg even with his problems of concentration and hyperactivity he knew how to control them and satisfy his viewers. Andrew Garfield as Eduardo also play a great role as being the best friend of Mark Zuckenberg, and he could express with great distress the courage and anger Eduardo had when Mark made a bad play with him.

In a movie like the Social Network a university environment is needed for a better expression, that's why a good setting didn't missed. As we know Mark Zuckenberg studied at Harvard University, so that's why most of the movie was film at it. This help to create a teenager environment, were we could see a better expression of romance, disputes, drugs, parties and among other universities things.

The Social Network has a lot of impressive exponents, but as we know perfect movies don't exist, that's why in this movie we may find some tiny defects. In the movie we may find suddenly changes of scenes from the interrogation to Mark, to the sequence of the creation of the social network. At first this is confusing but later you recognize what this means. I had like to know more about the ending relationship between Mark and Erika Albright after all what they passed thru the movie. These are some of the details we could find, but as I said they are just tiny defects.

This movie has shared to us the way of how Facebook was created. Most people thought that this movie was going to be like a documentary, so they obviously thought it was going to be bored. All their ideas about the movie change when they felt the delicious combination of History, love, troubles, and impressive ideas. This film let us know facts we didn't know about the creation of this impressive social network. If I had to rate this movie I will give to it a 9/10, and remember that if you want to know more of this impressive film, you just have to Log in.

title: Amazing film, great performances, script and of course directing
review:
So, The Social Network. This movie is incredible, it is awesome, and after you've seen it, it makes you wonder how this story worked so well as a drama, and not as a documentary or something. It has a very interesting story, if you haven't seen this, go watch it, really, after I saw it I looked up the writers, directors and I'm looking forward to seeing more from Aaron Sorkin and David Fincher.

The acting in The Social Network is absolutely first-rate, Jesse Eisenberg is incredible in this movie, it's like he was born to play this role, he talks fast, he's kind of geeky looking, he was perfect as Mark Zuckerberg, he really deserved an Oscar for it. I gotta say, after this, he's an actor to watch out for. Although Eisenberg was incredible, the person who literally stunned me with his acting was Andrew Garfield, this is the second film I've seen that stars him, I saw The Amazing Spider Man, he was decent in that movie, but here, he is outstanding in this movie as Zuckerberg's friend, Eduardo Saverin(Vai Brasil!) I was on his side the entire movie, partially because Zuckerberg's a dick, but also because of Garfield's acting, really something, I can't believe he didn't get at least an Oscar nomination, he was robbed right there. The weakest actor in the movie was Justin Timberlake, but he wasn't bad either.

The writing in this film is also outstanding, every single line of dialogue is so interesting, the story is really incredible, Aaron Sorkin, this guy is incredible, he really made this movie fantastic with the screenplay.

And wow, the soundtrack, another incredible aspect of the movie, every scene went along perfectly with the music, I loved the slow pace of the soundtrack, it really suited the film impeccably, it is very memorable, one of the best scores I've heard.

The directing is also amazing, David Fincher made a masterpiece. He made even the scenes that were supposed to be super boring, like the rowing scenes, and made them awesome. I can't really describe it, but he showed a style of shooting that's really different from other directors, I can tell this guy is great, because he made a movie about Facebook, and it's not boring, it's great, you get so invested in the story, and the way it's told, with scenes about the lawsuits in between the actual story, and as time passes, it explains everything, why those guys were suing Zuckerberg, and it worked incredibly well for the movie. I look forward to seeing more from him.

The Social Network is a fantastic movie, really, all aspects are amazing, everything goes together so well, and it doesn't make much sense that it's so good, it's a movie that could have been a documentary, but the people in charge of this made a true masterpiece, I strongly recommend this movie, really go watch it! I give it a well deserved 10/10.

title: Truthful movie about people's relationships
review:
21st century can't be 21st century without Internet. And Internet is not Internet without social networks. Nowadays every single person – from little kids to old grandparents – use Facebook. More than a billion people have an account there. This website turned the world on 180 degrees.

Everybody knows who is Mark Zuckerberg – the founder of Facebook, the most popular website on the Earth. And now imagine that creator of "Fight Club" will make a movie about him. And you will get "The Social Network" – the triumphant return of the great director David Fincher.

I never liked the idea of biopic genre – all movies in that expect "A Beautiful Mind" are bad. But "The Social Network" changed my opinion about that.

Almost every single detail of the picture is perfect – Fincher know how to do everything perfectly and how to keep audience at the screens throughout the film. One of my favorite things in the movie is the work of cinematographer – I enjoyed his shooting style and how he competently picked frames. I think it is one of the best cinematographer's work I have ever seen. Also hard work of screenwriter Aaron Sorkin is magnificent: the film literally can disassemble the citations.

But my favorite thing is cast: Brilliant acting play of Jessie Eisenberg struck me and made me change an opinion about him into the positive way. Also work of Andrew Garfield I liked very much – he did really good and from this moment for me he is not only associated with Spider Man.

Besides positive moments this picture has some problems: Sometimes the film sags and loses rhythm, but fortunately it happens for a couple minutes and then the picture starts to grow again. Very well chosen slogan: You can't get 500 million friends without making a few enemies – this movie not only about creating Facebook, but also about human relationships. Usually when someone achieves something really big other people begin to envy him. It happens always and especially in huge businesses. And it also happened to Mark Zuckerberg – everybody wanted to be in deal with him to earn tons of money. And also I can add very good phrase to this movie: Old friends and old vine are best – about conflict of two best friend Mark and Eduardo. Money always make people worse, and even best friends can become total enemies cause of that.

I think "The Social Network" is a brilliant movie and almost everything about it is perfect. It is very inspiring story that really convinces to do something. I liked it a lot.

title: Great movie
review:
Great movie on the founding and rise of Facebook, and the business machinatians that went on behind the scenes. Focuses primarily on Mark Zuckerberg, the CEO of Facebook, and he doesn't come out looking good.

Despite the less-than-flattering portrayal of Zuckerberg, and the room for poetic licence, the movie comes across as objective and factual (and I wouldn't know myself how true it all is). Very believable.

Great direction by David Fincher. Pace is intense, and never lets up. No red herrings or unnecessary detours. Camera angles and the like are spot on.

Good performances all round. Jesse Eisenberg is very believable as Zuckerberg. Andrew Garfield plays Eduardo Saverin, co-founder, and does a good job.

Surprise performance is from Justin Timberlake. Who knew he could act? (His music sucks, so I always knew he was no musician!). Although he has been in a few movies previously, he has never had a major role, and I have always regarded him as appearing in movies to add star appeal, rather than for his acting ability. He is excellent in this, though you feel this is the role he was born to play, as the personality and life of Sean Parker seems very much like that of pop star.

No matter how much truth there is in the story, a great movie and definitely worth the watch. Only proviso: if you're one of the few not on Facebook, many of the technical details will go over your head.

title: A Great Movie but even better screenplay
review:
The real star of this film is the extraordinary screenplay written by Aaron Sorkin. The characters he creates here are dark, flawed, and the epitome of the worst of the 2000s culture that the target audience of the film sprang from. Fincher does a fabulous job of interpreting this and bringing it to life on the screen. His visual of the script is bold and vibrant, exactly what was called for by the script.

The problem with this film is that the performances aren't really that spectacular. They are good enough to carry the film but that's the best I can say for them. Armie Hammer as the Winklevoss twins was probably the weakest link of the bunch. He hammed it up big time and turned them into caricatures. I still haven't figured out why Jesse Eisenberg's performance was so applauded. The performance at times was two dimensional.

All in all this is a great film. Fincher has done better with "The Curious Case of Benjamin Buttons" but this was arguably one of the better films of the years.

title: Chilling and cinematically beautiful; a true directory masterwork
review:
The Social Network depicts Mark Zuckerberg's, played by Jesse Eisenberg, oftentimes legitimately challenged rise to the top. The movie is ultimately a drawn-out court session in which Zuckerberg and his once best friend Eduardo look back on the past to decipher a long line of fraudulencies all starting with Eduardos investment into thefacebook. The Social Networks looks to unveil the brutal struggle for profit, what it stems from, and whether it was really intentional.

The acting was impeccable, making the tension between Eduardo and Mark almost tangible. Justin Timberlakes performance was very impressive and genuinely portrayed Sean Parkers personality (in the movie, I personally don't know much about his real personality). Another familiar face which I managed to recognize with a bit of research was Brenda song in her more serious role, known for Zack and Cody.

The pacing of the movie was amazing. The beginning was extremely intriguing and kept me on the edge of my seat. The prolonged court session had me trailing of a bit, but I guess it was the foundation of the movie. The movie had me sympathize with Mark at the beginning, but had me doubting his decisions towards the end. The movie managed to maintain a relatively neutral viewpoint on what happened between Marks ''invention'' of Facebook and it hitting 1 million users, and deserves a lot of recognition.

title: Mark Zuckerberg and the story of Facebook...
review:
"The Social Network" is a movie which shows us the true story of Mark Zuckerberg who is now a well known person because of his creation, the Facebook. It shows us also all the story between him and two brothers who sued him because they claimed that he stole their idea. Another thing that this movie shows us is that Mark Zuckerberg squeezed out of the business his best friend and co-founder of Facebook.

I liked this movie because is based on a true story facts and because of the direction of David Fincher which I think that it was just magnificent. I also liked the interpretations of Jesse Eisenberg's who plays as Mark Zuckerberg, Andrew Garfield's who plays as Eduardo Saverin the co-founder of Mark Zuckerberg and Rooney Mara's who plays as Erica Albright and is simply beautiful.

Finally I have to say that "The Social Network" is a really nice movie which I believe that everyone have to watch it because it shows us many things that all of us must watch and think about them.

title: I learned many things from this film.
review: This film is about Mark Zuckerberg creates Facebook and how to make Facebook. Before watching this film, I've never known about him. After watching this film, I'm not impressed by him. However, I really respect him because he made the most wonderful website in the world. I think everyone watches this movie won't have good impression of him because this film makes him bad man. I don't know what is fact and what is a fiction in this film. However from the directorial technique of this film, everything looks like fact. I think actors in this film are very nice. I really think Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg and I dislike him from bottom of my heart in the scene he gets on girl's bad side. From this film I learned that importance of decision and awfulness of desire. I think Mark mistook what he chooses because he wants to make Facebook cool more and more. This film makes us think importance of decision and awfulness of desire.

title: The Social Network
review: This movie is based on the true story of Mark Zuckerberg who is the Facebook founder. The boy who became the youngest billionaire in the world lose his family, best friend and lover on the way that he reaches the top. This movie is different from the simple success story of the man who get millions wealth and fame. In contrast with the rhythm that picture and BGM flowing slowly, characters have a speedy conversation. The discord between them is interesting. Although there are various movie, I felt empty after watching this movie. Portraiture of Mark Zuckerberg is consistent from the beginning to the last. He changes nothing whereas Facebook he made grows up steadily. It is surprising that the man who makes the Facebook lacks communication skill. Various human relations in the modern society are drawn cleverly. It can be never said that it was an interesting work, but it makes me think about various things.

title: speedy and humorous movie
review:
The mark (Jasey Eisenberg) of the 19-year-old student who goes to Harvard University begins to make the site for increasing a friend in a university together with best friend Eduard (Andrew Garfield). A site spreads among college students in an instant. By encounter with Sean (Justin Timberlake), the Napster founder, it grows up to be a global huge site finally. This movie is very speedy and a humorous conversation is incorporated. Background from the launch of Facebook to have drawn to this. In addition, risk , enthusiasm and readiness of his on making Facebook is depicted interesting.

Mark is a geek and gloomy. He is not good at getting along with people, but I am favor him for some reason. I think I often use the net every day, but people who really ignorant PC cannot understand this movie. I thought it was like a Hollywood movie to realize the American Dream.

title: Film Appreciation Review
review:
"The Social Network" takes you on the journey to the top of social media, but also takes you on the journey of Mark Zuckerberg's college life. Mark faces a break-up, gains/losses friends, goes through two tough law suits, and makes millions of dollars. Mark, played by actor Jesse Eidenberg, goes through what seems like a tough break up (not because they have been dating for a long time, but more because Mark does not take rejection well). This break up sparks a late night drunken blog spree that ends with Mark creating Facemash, an online hot or not rating system for female college undergraduates. This is the first time you see just how truly brilliant Mark is when it comes to network programming and breaching systems security. Mark's partner in crime, Eduardo Saverin, helps Mark with the rating algorithm for Facemash. In this scene, you get the sense that with these two Harvard geniuses' they could create any type of computer/internet programming.

Facemash eventually crashed the Harvard network and Mark does get into some academic trouble for hacking the system to obtain the needed pictures of the undergraduates, but with this stunt he gets the attention of some other students. Cameron, Tyler, and Henry are also Harvard students that seek out Mark to ask him to be their network programmer for a social media idea that they have. Mark agrees to help them, but in the end never does as the idea they present to Mark is filled with issues. Mark does however elaborate on their idea and partners with Eduardo to ultimately create Facebook. Mark is the brains and the programmer of Facebook; Eduardo is the financial backing and marketing of Facebook. The movie portrays that fame, no matter how much or how little, can divide even the closest of friends. Even though it was out of spite and to prove he could, Mark created Facebook to generate a social media craze that would bring college students together and make it easier and more enjoyable for them to communicate. He sought out to bring people closer but in the end it tore his social life apart.

Facebook takes off quicker than Mark and Eduardo could ever imagine.
